{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}}
[[File:Judy Garland-publicity.JPG|thumb|Actress and singer [[Judy Garland]] is cited as one of the quintessential gay icons.]] A '''gay icon''' is a [[public figure]] (historical or present) who is embraced by many within [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) communities.
Some of the main qualities of a gay icon often include [[glamour (presentation)|glamour]], [[wikt:flamboyant|flamboyance]], strength through adversity, and [[androgyny]] in presentation. Such icons can be of any [[sexual orientation]] or [[gender]]; if LGBT, they can be [[Coming out|out]] or not. Although most gay icons have given their support to [[LGBT social movements]], some have expressed [[LGBT rights opposition|opposition]], advocating against a perceived "[[homosexual agenda]]".
Historically, icons were typically elevated to such status because their sexual orientation remains a topic of debate among historians. Modern gay icons are predominantly female entertainers who commonly garner a large following within LGBT communities over the course of their careers.
{{TOC limit|3}}
==Historical== [[File:Sodoma 003.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Saint Sebastian]], history's first recorded gay icon]] The earliest gay icon may have been [[Saint Sebastian]],<ref name="QUEER">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/arts/subjects_st_sebastian.html |title=Subjects of the Visual Arts: St. Sebastian |work=[[glbtq.com]] |accessdate=August 1, 2007 |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901002221/http://www.glbtq.com/arts/subjects_st_sebastian.html |archivedate=September 1, 2007}}</ref> a Christian saint and [[martyr]], whose combination of strong and shirtless physique, [[Phallic symbol|symbolic arrow-pierced]] flesh and rapturous look of pain have intrigued artists, both gay and straight, for centuries and began the first explicitly gay cult in the nineteenth century.<ref name="QUEER" /> Journalist Richard A. Kaye wrote, "Contemporary gay men have seen in Sebastian at once a stunning advertisement for homosexual desire (indeed, a [[Homoeroticism|homoerotic]] ideal), and a prototypical portrait of a tortured closet case."<ref name="QUEER2">{{cite journal |last=Kaye |first=Richard A. |title=Losing His Religion: Saint Sebastian as Contemporary Gay Martyr |journal=Outlooks: Lesbian and Gay Sexualities and Visual Cultures.'' Peter Horne and Reina Lewis, eds.'' |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |year=1996 |volume=86|page=105 |doi=10.4324/9780203432433_chapter_five}}</ref>
Due to Saint Sebastian's status as a gay icon, [[Tennessee Williams]] chose to use the saint's name for the martyred character Sebastian in his play, ''[[Suddenly, Last Summer]]''.<ref name=tnwilliams>{{cite web |url=http://www.trinityrep.com/DownloadDocs/Suddenly_Last_Summer_SG.pdf |format=PDF |title=Tiny Rep presents ''Suddenly, Last Summer'' |accessdate=August 1, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928002111/http://www.trinityrep.com/DownloadDocs/Suddenly_Last_Summer_SG.pdf |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The name was also used by [[Oscar Wilde]]—as Sebastian Melmoth—when in exile after his release from prison. Wilde, an Irish writer and poet, was about as "[[out of the closet]]" as was possible for the late 19th century, and is himself considered to be a gay icon.<ref>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/markets/europe/article1289533.ece Vatican comes out of the closet and embraces Oscar]; Richard Owen, [[The Times]]; January 5, 2007. Retrieved October 14, 2007.</ref>
[[Marie Antoinette]] was an early lesbian icon. Rumors about her relationships with women circulated in pornographic detail by anti-royalist pamphlets before the [[French Revolution]]. In [[Victorian era|Victorian England]], biographers who idealized the [[Ancien Régime]] made a point of denying the rumours, but at the same time romanticised Marie Antoinette's "sisterly" friendship with the [[Princesse de Lamballe]] as—in the words of an 1858 biography—one of the "rare and great loves that Providence unites in death."<ref name="afraser" /> By the end of the 19th century, she was a cult icon of "[[Terminology of homosexuality#Sapphism|sapphism]]." Her execution, seen as tragic martyrdom, may have added to her appeal.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
Allusions to her appearance were made in early 20th century [[lesbian literature]]—most notably [[Radclyffe Hall]]'s ''[[The Well of Loneliness]]''—where the gay playwright Jonathan Brockett describes Marie Antoinette and de Lamballe as "poor souls... sick to death of the subterfuge and pretenses."<ref name="Castle">{{cite book |last=Castle |first=Terry |title=The Apparitional Lesbian: Female Homosexuality and Modern Culture |publisher=[[Columbia University Press]] |year=1993 |location=New York |pages=126–149 and 261n56 |isbn=0-231-07652-5}}</ref> She had crossover appeal as a gay icon, as well, at least for French novelist, playwright, poet, essayist, and political activist [[Jean Genet]], who was fascinated by her story. He included a reenactment of her execution in his 1947 play ''[[The Maids]]''.<ref name=afraser>{{cite book |last=Fraser |first=Antonia |authorlink=Antonia Fraser |title=Marie Antoinette: The Journey |publisher=Anchor |year=2001 |location=New York |page=449 |isbn=0-385-48949-8}}</ref>
==Modern== [[File:Marlon Brando 1948.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Bisexual icon [[Marlon Brando]]]] Modern gay icons in entertainment include film stars and musicians, most of whom have strong, distinctive personalities, and many of whom died young or under tragic circumstances. For example, Greek-American opera singer [[Maria Callas]]—who reached her peak in the 1950s—became a gay icon because the uniquely compelling qualities of her stage performances were allied to a tempestuous private life, a sequence of unhappy love affairs, and a lonely premature death in Paris after her voice had deserted her.
Lesbian icons, sometimes called "dykons" (a [[portmanteau]] of the words "dyke" and "icon") are most often powerful women who are, or are rumored to be, lesbian or bisexual.<ref name=Dykon>Euan Ferguson, [https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2003/feb/16/features.review147 Daniela's still dying for it]; February 16, 2003; Retrieved February 8, 2007: ''All over the South-East men fell in lust with the idea of a fast lippy sexy Scot, and I'm told she also became something of a dykon, a female gay icon.''</ref><ref name="POP">{{cite web |url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/column/gay-icons-judy-who/ |title=Queer, Isn't It?: Gay Icons: Judy Who? |date=November 16, 2006 |accessdate=August 1, 2007 |first=Michael |last=Abernethy |work=[[PopMatters]]}}</ref> However, a few male entertainers have also had iconic status for lesbian people. [[James Dean]] was an early lesbian icon who, along with [[Marlon Brando]], influenced the [[Butch and femme|butch]] look and self-image in the 1950s and after.<ref name=jdean>{{cite journal |last=Pramaggiore |first=Maria |title=Fishing For Girls: Romancing Lesbians in New Queer Cinema |journal=College Literature |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=59–75 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3709/is_199702/ai_n8753202/pg_11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014045558/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3709/is_199702/ai_n8753202/pg_11 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-14 |date=February 1997 |accessdate=February 9, 2007}}</ref><ref name=mbrando>{{cite book |last=Kennedy |first=Elizabeth Lapovsky |author2=Madeline D. Davis |title=Boots of Leather, Slippers of Gold: The History of a Lesbian Community |publisher=Penguin |year=1994 |location=New York |isbn=0-14-023550-7 |pages=212–213}}</ref><ref name=skirting>{{cite journal |last=Blackman |first=Inge |author2=Kathryn Perry |title=Skirting the Issue: Lesbian Fashion for the 1990s |journal=Feminist Review |issue=34 |pages=67–78 |year=1990 |volume=0 |doi=10.2307/1395306 |jstor=1395306}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Halberstam |first=Judith |title=Female Masculinity |publisher=[[Duke University Press]] |year=1998 |location=Durham, NC |page=330 |isbn=0-8223-2243-9}}</ref> One critic has argued for [[Johnny Cash]] as a minor lesbian icon, attributing his appeal to "lesbian identification with troubled and suffering masculinity."<ref name=jcash>Ortega, Teresa. "'My Name is Sue! How do you do?': Johnny Cash as Lesbian Icon". In {{cite book |last=Tichi |first=Cecilia |title=Reading Country Music: Steel Guitars, Opry Stars, and Honky-Tonk Bars |publisher=Duke University Press |year=1998 |location=Durham, NC |page=222 |url= |isbn=0-8223-2168-8}}</ref> Science fiction author [[Forrest J Ackerman]] was dubbed an "honorary lesbian" for his help during the early days of lesbian rights organisation [[Daughters of Bilitis]]. He also wrote lesbian-themed fiction under the pseudonym Laurajean Ermayne.
Gay icons may be homosexual or heterosexual, out or [[Coming out|in the closet]], male or female. The women most commonly portrayed by [[drag queen]]s are usually gay icons. The definition of what it means to be a "gay icon" has come under criticism in recent years for a lack of substance. [[Paul Flynn (politician)|Paul Flynn]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote, "The concept of gay icon is a cheap ticket...[and] the idea of gay iconography itself is currently replaceable with the idea of popularity and the ability to carry a strong, identifiable, [[trademark look|signature look]]."<ref name=EYE>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/may/16/bypaulflynn |title=Margaret Thatcher: gay icon |last=Flynn |first=Paul |work=The Guardian |location=London|date=May 16, 2006 |accessdate=April 17, 2017}}</ref> Author [[Michael Thomas Ford]] depicts a similar attitude in his work of fiction ''Last Summer''.
===Non-American cultures=== Although the term "gay icon" is most commonly used in the United States, the concept is found in other cultures, as well. [[Dalida]], an Egyptian singer of Italian origin, had a career-long gay following that extended out of Paris and well into the Middle East. In the years since her death, her iconic status has not diminished.<ref name=dalida>{{cite web |url=http://www.viator.com/tours/Paris/Private-Gay-Paris-Walking-Tour-Pere-Lachaise-Cemetery-and-Montmartre/d479-3061MON |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117165709/http://www.viator.com/tours/Paris/Private-Gay-Paris-Walking-Tour-Pere-Lachaise-Cemetery-and-Montmartre/d479-3061MON |archivedate=January 17, 2008 |title=Gay Montmartre Tour |accessdate=August 1, 2007}}</ref><ref name=dalida2>{{cite web|first=David |last=France |url=http://men.style.com/gq/features/landing?id=content_5304 |title=Dying to come out:The war on gay people in Iraq |work=[[GQ magazine]] |date=February 2007 |accessdate=February 7, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513201216/http://men.style.com/gq/features/landing?id=content_5304 |archivedate=May 13, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[File:Dalida19673.jpg|thumb|[[Dalida]] in 1967]]
====Asian==== As a result of their pro-LGBT activism and their artistry, Taiwanese singers [[A-mei]] and [[Jolin Tsai]], Indian actor [[Anil Kapoor]] and Indian actress [[Sonam Kapoor]] and Hong Kong singer, [[Leslie Cheung]] have been called gay icons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodlife.com/news-gossip/heres-how-anil-kapoor-became-the-newest-gay-icon/ |title=Here’s how Anil Kapoor became the newest gay icon! |publisher=Bollywoodlife.com |date=2015-09-08 |accessdate=2018-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-is-sonam-kapoor-indias-new-gay-icon/20110627.htm |title=Is Sonam Kapoor India's new gay icon? - Rediff.com Movies |publisher=Rediff.com |date=2011-06-27 |accessdate=2018-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ho |first=Gwyneth |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-43637749 |title=Leslie Cheung: Asia's gay icon lives on 15 years after his death - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.com |date= |accessdate=2018-10-21}}</ref>
====European==== Similarly, in European countries such as the [[Netherlands]], Dutch singer and actress [[Willeke Alberti]] is widely embraced as a gay icon, due to a combination of her song repertoire, her durability, and her performances in support of manifold gay causes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gayinfo.tripod.com/WOF.html |title=Foot and Hand Prints in Rotterdam |publisher=Gayinfo.tripod.com |accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref> Spanish actress [[Carmen Maura]], Spanish politician [[Pedro Zerolo]],<ref name="cascaraamarga.es">[http://www.cascaraamarga.es/sociedad/gente/11569-fallece-pedro-zerolo-un-icono-del-activismo-lgtb.html «Fallece Pedro Zerolo, un icono del activismo LGTB.»]</ref> Italian singer [[Mina Mazzini|Mina]], and [[Raffaella Carrà]], Scottish pop singer [[Jimmy Somerville]], German actress and singer [[Hildegard Knef]] and English singers [[Dusty Springfield]] and [[Sophie Ellis-Bextor]] are also considered gay icons,<ref>''The Guardian'' (August 13, 2006). [https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/aug/13/features.review1 'Sex was my way of coping with death'] (interview with Pedro Almodóvar). Retrieved June 14, 2008.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lostiempos.com/noticias/17-01-07/17_01_07_inter6.php |title=El Papa es impopular entre gays |work=Los Tiempos |date=January 17, 2007 |accessdate=June 22, 2008 |archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071110014950/http://www.lostiempos.com/noticias/17-01-07/17_01_07_inter6.php |archivedate=November 10, 2007 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="showbizie">{{Cite news |title=Joss, Lionel & Jimmy Play Dublin... |url=http://www.showbiz.ie/news/november04/04-stone01.shtml |date=April 11, 2004 |accessdate=November 26, 2007 |periodical=ShowBiz Ireland}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.de/Hildegard-Knef-Eine-K%C3%BCnstlerin-Deutschland/dp/3865051677 |title=Hildegard Knef. Eine Künstlerin aus Deutschland |accessdate=April 9, 2016}}</ref><ref name="DustySpringfield">{{cite news |first=Michele |last=Kort |title=The secret life of Dusty Springfield |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_1999_April_27/ai_54492600/print |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050506051402/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_1999_April_27/ai_54492600/print |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 6, 2005 |work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]] |date=April 27, 1999 |accessdate=April 10, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/murder-on-the-dance-floor-a-quick-tango-with-sophie-ellisbextor-8894430.html | title= Murder on the dance floor: a quick tango with Sophie Ellis-Bextor |publisher= The Standard |accessdate= October 21, 2013}}</ref> as are French entertainers [[Dalida]], [[Mylène Farmer]], [[Lorie (singer)|Lorie]], [[Jenifer (singer)|Jenifer]], [[Alizée]] and [[Ysa Ferrer]], Ukrainian boy band [[Kazaky]], Turkish singer [[Ajda Pekkan]] and Italian actress [[Isabella Rossellini]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://daily.gay.com/entertainment/2010/11/ukraines-hottest-boy-band.html |title=Ukraine's Hottest Boy Band |accessdate=November 22, 2010 |last=Matson |first=Michael |date=November 22, 2010 |work=Geek Out |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125145323/http://daily.gay.com/entertainment/2010/11/ukraines-hottest-boy-band.html |archivedate=November 25, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name="kaosgl1">{{cite web |url=http://www.kaosgl.com/sayfa.php?id=9095 |title=Türkiye'nin 'gay ikonu' Hande Yener |accessdate=January 19, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105074434/http://www.kaosgl.com/sayfa.php?id=9095 |archive-date=November 5, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenewgay.net/2010/05/isabella-rossellini-fashion-and-gay-icon-to-make-film-series.html |title=Isabella Rossellini: Fashion and Gay icon to make film series |publisher=The New Gay |date=May 3, 2010 |accessdate=December 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312013924/http://thenewgay.net/2010/05/isabella-rossellini-fashion-and-gay-icon-to-make-film-series.html |archivedate=March 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Latin America==== Latin American figures have also gained reputations as gay icons. Pop band [[Alaska y Dinarama]] is one example. Their single "[[¿A quién le importa?]]" ("Who Cares?"), which was later covered in 2002 by [[Thalía]], was a hit for the 1980s Spanish band, becoming a [[gay anthem]] for the [[Hispanophone]] LGBT community. Singer [[Gloria Trevi]] is considered a gay icon, especially after her release of "[[Todos Me Miran]]" ("They All Are Looking at Me") featuring a rejected gay man turned drag queen, but had been popular with the gay and lesbian community in Mexico since the beginning of her career for being a controversial and powerful singer.<ref>{{cite news |title=An anti-diva returns to thank her fans |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/headline/entertainment/5438315.html |work=Houston Chronicle |date=January 10, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2009}}</ref> Mexican singer and actress [[Paulina Rubio]] has been a gay icon for Latin America after supporting gay marriage and publicly stating that she wants to have sex with fellow gay icon [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Gonzalez |first=Lisa |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1613712/20090610/story.jhtml |title=Paulina Rubio Inspired By Miami For New Album And Video |work=Mtv |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref>
Other modern Latin American gay icons include singers [[Alaska (singer)|Alaska]], [[Ricky Martin]], [[La Lupe]], [[Sara Montiel]], [[Lola Flores]] and [[Chavela Vargas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agmagazine.info/2009/06/20/de-lo-gay-hay-que-hablar-en-positivo-dice-la-cantante-alaska/ |title=Alaska says we should refer to "gay" as a positive thing |publisher=Agmagazine.info |date=June 20, 2009 |accessdate=April 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407061349/http://www.agmagazine.info/2009/06/20/de-lo-gay-hay-que-hablar-en-positivo-dice-la-cantante-alaska/ |archivedate=April 7, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Enrique-Loves-The-Gay-Life-58725.shtml |title=Enrique Loves Gay Life – Softpedia |publisher=News.softpedia.com |accessdate=December 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223175839/http://news.softpedia.com/news/Enrique-Loves-The-Gay-Life-58725.shtml |archivedate=December 23, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Argentine gay icons include actresses [[Isabel Sarli]], [[Susana Giménez]] and [[Moria Casán]], the [[trans woman]] [[Florencia De La V|Florencia de la V]], First Lady [[Eva Perón]] and President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]].<ref name="terra.com.ar">{{cite web|url=http://edant.revistaenie.clarin.com/notas/2009/12/29/_-02109944.htm|language=Spanish|title=Iconos y técnicas de conquista en la primera enciclopedia gay argentina|work=Ñ|publisher=''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]''|date=December 29, 2009|accessdate=November 10, 2013}}</ref>
Venezuelan actresses Mimi Lazo, Haydée Balza, Lila Morillo, Mirtha Perez, Kiara and Hilda Abrahamz are the most beloved gay icons in the country, often impersonated by drag queens. Other artist who have fought for gay rights in the country are the model and actress Patricia Velazquez, the playwriter Isaac Chocrón, the journalist Boris Izaguirre, the actors Edgar Ramirez and Luis Fernandez as for the youtuber Pedro Figueira known as La Divaza.
In Brazil, pop singers [[Kelly Key]], [[Sandy (singer)|Sandy]], [[Lorena Simpson]], [[Preta Gil]], and [[Wanessa]] are considered gay icons. In 2012, Key was honored with the "Pink Triangle Award," a Brazilian LGBT award, considered the "Gay Oscar".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://g1.globo.com/pop-arte/noticia/2012/04/meu-publico-gay-agora-tem-idade-para-ir-boates-diz-kelly-key.html|title=Meu público gay agora tem idade para ir a boates, diz Kelly Key|publisher=G1 News|date=June 14, 2012 |accessdate=June 17, 2012 |location=Brazil}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://virgula.uol.com.br/ver/noticia/musica/2012/03/24/296939-eu-sou-a-favor-do-casamento-gay-revela-sandy-em-entrevista#8|title="Eu sou a favor do casamento gay", revela Sandy em entrevista|publisher=Virgula Uol News|date=June 14, 2012 |accessdate=June 17, 2012 |location=Brazil}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://g1.globo.com/pop-arte/noticia/2011/08/publico-gay-foi-o-primeiro-abracar-novo-trabalho-diz-wanessa-camargo.html|title=Público gay foi o primeiro a abraçar novo trabalho, diz Wanessa Camargo|publisher=G1 News|date=June 14, 2012 |accessdate=June 17, 2012 |location=Brazil}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://terramagazine.terra.com.br/interna/0,,OI5647606-EI6594,00-Gays+criticam+Dilma+Cro+e+Minotauro+e+entregam+Oscar+a+inimigos.html|title=Gays criticam Dilma, Crô e Minotauro e entregam "Oscar"|work=Terra|date=August 17, 2012|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
===Entertainment===
====20th century====
=====1930s–1940s===== The 1930s saw a number of writers, political activists, and celebrities garner reputations as gay icons. Poet and satirical writer [[Dorothy Parker]] reportedly had a large gay following. Though the phrase "[[friend of Dorothy]]" was made popular in later years by Judy Garland's role in ''The Wizard Of Oz'' (1939), some{{who|date=January 2017}} speculate it originated with Parker.
[[File:Bette Davis Glamorous in Dark Victory trailer.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Bette Davis]] in the 1939 film ''[[Dark Victory]]'']] Actress [[Bette Davis]]' performance in ''[[Dark Victory]]'' (1939), was dubbed by [[Queer theory|queer theorist]] Eve Sedgwick as "the epistemology of [[the closet]]."<ref name="Dark Victory">{{cite book |last=Sikov |first=Ed |title=Dark Victory: The Life of Bette Davis |publisher=Macmillan |year=2007 |page=139 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=W7qpYrkAXw8C|isbn=0-8050-7548-8}}</ref> Davis' portrayal of the melodramatic [[Judith Traherne]] made her talent for playing someone with a secret revered and her "camp-worthy" dialog reflexive of the "flamboyant gay queen of the dramatic arts."<ref name="Dark Victory" /> Ed Sikov, author of ''Dark Victory: The Life of Bette Davis'', wrote that 20th century gay men developed their own subculture following Davis' example.<ref name="Dark Victory" />
In [[Marcella Althaus-Reid]]'s ''Liberation Theology and Sexuality'', [[Marlene Dietrich]], who is considered to be the first German-born actress to receive critical acclaim in Hollywood, is a model of liberation and subversion, as well as beauty, perfection and sensuality.<ref name=dietrich>{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/books/12/25/marlene.dietrich/index.html |title=Review: 'Dietrich' beautiful photo collection |last=Dunn |first=Andrew |work=[[CNN]].com |date=December 25, 2001 |accessdate=August 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016163924/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/books/12/25/marlene.dietrich/index.html |archivedate=October 16, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Dietrich">{{cite book |last=Althaus-Reid |first=Marcella |title=Liberation Theology and Sexuality |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. |year=2006 |page=134 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=LD5nkd_1iKcC|isbn=0-7546-5080-4}}</ref> In [[Rio de Janeiro]], Althaus-Reid discovered a statue of Dietrich dressed as [[Our Lady of Aparecida]] in a gay bar in [[Copacabana (Rio de Janeiro)|Copacabana]] beach.<ref name="Dietrich" /> The image of Dietrich as the [[Black Madonna|black Virgin Mary]] represents her overcoming duality.<ref name="Dietrich" /> According to Althaus-Reid, it is a figure that sanctifies Dietrich while simultaneously liberating Mary.<ref name="Dietrich" />
Other icons from this time period include [[Cary Grant]], who endured speculation over his alleged relationships with men.
=====1950s–1960s===== {{See also|Judy Garland as gay icon}} [[File:Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz trailer.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Judy Garland]], arguably the most famous gay icon, as [[Dorothy Gale]] in ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1939)]] An [[archetypal]] gay icon is [[Judy Garland]].<ref name=judy>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.org/Template.cfm?Section=Home&CONTENTID=9115&TEMPLATE=/ContentManagement/ContentDisplay.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930031343/http://www.hrc.org/Template.cfm?Section=Home&CONTENTID=9115&TEMPLATE=%2FContentManagement%2FContentDisplay.cfm |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |title=Cher: Last of the Gay Icons? |first=Michael |last=Westley |work=Salt Lake Tribune |date=August 13, 2002 |accessdate=August 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Michael Bronski]], author of ''Culture Clash: The Making of Gay Sensibility'', describes Garland as "the quintessential pre-[[Stonewall riots|Stonewall]] gay icon."<ref name="Culture Clash">{{cite book |last=Bronski |first=Michael |title=Culture Clash: The Making of Gay Sensibility |publisher=South End Press |year=1984 |page=104 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QBOARyvN-cMC|isbn=0-89608-217-2}}</ref> So revered is she as a gay icon that her best known film role, [[Dorothy Gale]] in ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', became used as code among homosexuals in the 1950s.<ref name="Gayle">{{cite book |last=Cage |first=Ken |author2=Moyra Evans |title=Gayle: The Language of Kinks and Queens, A History and Dictionary of Gay Language in South Africa |publisher=Jacana Media |year=2003 |page=10 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=WSn7026sq_cC |isbn=1-919931-49-X}}</ref>
The expression "Is he a [[friend of Dorothy]]?" was slang for "Is he gay?"<ref name="Gayle" /> The character Dorothy meets an odd group of friends during her journey through Oz—the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion and the Scarecrow—and so referring to an individual as a "friend of Dorothy" meant that they were "unusual or odd" and, therefore, "queer".<ref name="Gayle" /> Though Garland has been noted for her embodiment of [[camp (style)|camp]] in her acting roles, Bronski argues that she was the "antithesis of camp" and "made a legend of her pain and oppression."<ref name="Culture Clash" /> As Bronski observes, the bleak setting of 1950s Hollywood had replaced the "sauciness of the [1930s] and the independence of the [1940s]."<ref name="Culture Clash" /> Garland, as well as [[Connie Francis]], [[Lana Turner]] and [[Susan Hayward]], epitomized the idea that "suffering was the price of glamor...[and] the women stars of the [1950s] reflected the condition of many gay men: they suffered, beautifully".<ref name="Culture Clash" />
[[File:Lucy YankArmy cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Actress [[Lucille Ball]] in 1945]] Garland's daughter [[Liza Minnelli]] would later follow in her mother's footsteps as a gay icon, as would fellow musical artist [[Barbra Streisand]].<ref name="POP" /><ref name="terra.com.ar"/> [[Joan Crawford]] has been described as the "ultimate gay icon—the martyr who suffered for her art and, therefore, enabled herself to bond with this all-important faction of her fanbase."<ref name="Joan Crawford">{{cite book |last=Bret |first=David |title=Joan Crawford: Hollywood Martyr |publisher=Da Capo Press |year=2008 |pages=192, 287 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=-cf2gT2bRG8C |isbn=0-306-81624-5}}</ref> In ''Joan Crawford: The Essential Biography'', author [[Lawrence J. Quirk]] explains that Crawford appealed to gay men because they sympathized with her struggle for success, in both the entertainment industry and in her personal life.<ref name="The Essential Biography">{{cite book |last=Quirk |first=Lawrence J. |author2=William Schoell|title=Joan Crawford: The Essential Biography |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |year=2002 |page=235 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=_yQtRavDvtUC |isbn=0-8131-2254-6}}</ref> Though Crawford had been a notable film star during the 1930s and 1940s, according to [[David Bret]], author of ''Joan Crawford: Hollywood Martyr'', it was not until her 1953 film ''[[Torch Song (1953 film)|Torch Song]]'' that she was seen as a "complete gay icon, primarily because it was shot in color." Bret explains that seeing the actress' red hair, dark eyes and "Victory Red" lips linked her to "gaydom's other sirens: Dietrich, Garland, Bankhead, Piaf, and new recruits [[Marilyn Monroe]] and Maria Callas."<ref name="Joan Crawford" />
Actress [[Lucille Ball]] was also a prominent icon from this period. In Lee Tannen's book ''I Loved Lucy: My Friendship with Lucille Ball'', the author describes his experience when he witnessed Lucille Ball being labeled a gay icon for the first time by a mutual friend.<ref name="Lucille Ball">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=LMaAn8OL6sgC&pg=PA120 |title=I Loved Lucy: My Friendship With Lucille Ball |work=St. Martin's Press |first=Lee |last=Tannen |year=2002 |accessdate=January 24, 2008 |isbn=978-0-312-30274-0}}</ref> Ball was told of the adoration she received from gay men, as a bar in [[West Hollywood]] was known for routinely playing episodes of her television series ''[[I Love Lucy]]'' every weekend.<ref name="Lucille Ball" />
=====1970s===== During the late 1970s, many female comedians appeared, joining the ranks of what had stereotypically been a male profession, including [[Joan Rivers]], who began appearing on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]''. Rivers gained a strong gay following after performing in [[Greenwich Village]], an LGBT friendly area of New York, from the early days of her career. Rivers' frank and sharp use of wit and insults (largely turned toward herself) made her an instant gay icon. [[File:Donna Summer 1977.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Donna Summer]] was a prominent gay icon of the underground gay disco scene.]]
The first gay icon of the 1970s underground gay disco scene was the "Queen of Disco" [[Donna Summer]], whose dance songs became [[Gay anthem|anthems for the clubbing gay community]], and her music the back beat to the battles of the gay rights movement of the 1970s.<ref name=pinklist>{{cite web |url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/articles/2005-3431.html |title=Gordon Ramsay 50th most popular gay icon |last=Grew |first=Tony |work=Pink News |date=January 5, 2007 |accessdate=August 1, 2007}}</ref> Her number one single "[[Love to Love You Baby (song)|Love to Love You Baby]]"—regarded as an "absolute disco epic"—not only became a gay anthem because of its "unabridged sexuality", but it also brought European-oriented disco to the United States and influenced the course the recording industry would take in the following years.<ref>{{cite book |last=Creswell |first=Toby |title=1001 Songs: The Great Songs of All Time and the Artists, Stories and Secrets Behind Them |publisher=Thunder's Mouth Press |year=2006 |page=175 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=A_xtSKdVGpQC |isbn=1-56025-915-9}}</ref> However, Summer became immersed in controversy when, after becoming a [[Born again (Christianity)|Born again Christian]], and during a 1983–84 tour, at the dawn of the [[HIV/AIDS]] crisis, she was allegedly reported as making homophobic remarks; including that "AIDS was God's punishment to homosexuals." Fellow disco singer [[Gloria Gaynor]] was embraced by the gay community because of her single "[[I Will Survive]]", which served as an anthem for both feminists and the gay rights movement.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sagert |first=Kelly Boyer |title=The 1970s |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2007 |page=183 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=9feBCLNhcFQC |isbn=0-313-33919-8}}</ref> The [[Village People]], a pioneering disco group, are also regarded as gay icons for bringing gay disco culture into the mainstream with their popular disco and dance hits; and their costumes, with each member of the group representing a part of gay erotica (a policeman, a sailor, a construction worker, a cowboy, a leather clad man).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.astabgay.com/Gay_Icons/village.htm |title=Village People – Gay Icons |publisher=Astabgay.com |date=March 4, 2001 |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref>
Actress [[Lynda Carter]] became a gay icon after starring as Wonder Woman in the 1975–1979 [[Wonder Woman (TV series)|series of the same name]]. Her role as the heroine attracted the LGBT community for her onscreen persona of female strength and fashionable outfits.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sean Bugg|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/feature/?ak=8393&pagenumber=all|title=Pride's Wonder Woman|work=[[Metro Weekly]]|date=June 6, 2013|accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> Carter is a vocal supporter of LGBT equality and has participated in the [[LGBT Pride March (New York City)|New York City Gay Pride Parade]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/interviews/2012/04/24/lynda-carter-wonder-woman-tour-album?page=0,0|title=The Further Adventures of Lynda Carter|author=Jase Peeples|work=[[Out (magazine)|Out]]|date=April 24, 2012|accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>
Singer [[Sylvester (singer)|Sylvester]] became a gay icon after releasing his [[Hi-NRG]] single "[[You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)]]" in 1978. Sylvester often made appearances in [[Drag queen|drag]], and often described as a disco diva because of his [[falsetto]] voice and flamboyant appearance. He also influenced the gay nightclub scene in the late seventies and eighties. Sylvester died of [[AIDS]]-related complications in [[1988]].<ref>https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/7850196/sylvester-pioneer-lgbtq</ref>
Singer [[Cass Elliot]] became known as a gay icon, both during her solo career and as a member of [[The Mamas & the Papas]]. Her musical impact became known through her camp fashion and lyrics praising individuality (such as "[[Make Your Own Kind of Music (song)|Make Your Own Kind of Music]]" and "Different") and free love. Her music was later featured in the acclaimed gay film ''[[Beautiful Thing (film)|Beautiful Thing]]'' (1996), adapted from the play of the same name.
Singer and actress [[Bette Midler]] became recognized as a gay icon in the 1970s. After performing on Broadway, Midler began performing at the [[Continental Baths]], a [[gay bathhouse]] in the city, where she became close to her piano accompanist [[Barry Manilow]], who produced her first major album ''[[The Divine Miss M]]'' (1973). "Despite the way things turned out [with the AIDS crisis], I'm still proud of those days [singing at gay bathhouses]. I feel like I was at the forefront of the gay liberation movement, and I hope I did my part to help it move forward. So, I kind of wear the label of 'Bathhouse Betty' with pride," Midler reminisced in 1998.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bette Midler |work=Houston Voice |date=October 23, 1998}}</ref>
[[Freddie Mercury]], the [[lead vocalist]] of [[Queen (band)|Queen]], was widely considered a gay icon,<ref name="Magill2012">{{cite book|author=R. Jay Magill|title=Sincerity: How a moral ideal born five hundred years ago inspired religious wars, modern art, hipster chic, and the curious notion that we all have something to say (no matter how dull) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dZh3DB7jj5wC&pg=PT163 |date=July 16, 2012 |publisher=W. W. Norton |isbn=978-0-393-08419-1 |page=163}}</ref> with his LGBT fanbase growing by the 1980s. Although Freddie Mercury [[Freddie Mercury#Sexual orientation|never revealed his sexuality publicly]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Januszczak|first=Waldemar |title=Star of India|publication-date=November 17, 1996 |periodical=The Sunday Times |location=London |url=http://queenarchives.com/index.php?title=Freddie_Mercury_-_11-17-1996_-_Sunday_Times}};{{cite web |last=Cain |first=Matthew, dir. |year=2006 |title=Freddie Mercury: A Kind of Magic |publisher=British Film Institute |location=London |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AQ1cfoMWRpQ}}.<!-- TIME: 9:00/Roger Taylor -->.<!-- BFI record: http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/824582 -->;{{cite web |last=Landesman |first=Cosmo |title=Freddie, a Very Private Rock Star|publication-date=September 10, 2006 |periodical=The Times |url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/news/article169146.ece |location=London |accessdate=May 2, 2010}}</ref> (even when events made it seem inevitable<ref>{{cite web|author1=Patricia Juliana Smith |title=Mercury, Freddie (1946-1991)|url=http://www.glbtqarchive.com/arts/mercury_f_A.pdf|publisher=[[glbtq.com|glbtq Inc.]] |accessdate=September 6, 2015 |date=2002}}</ref>), he often "playfully alluded to his queerness with his flamboyant, high-camp stage antics", according to ''[[Gay Star News]]''.<ref name=GSN1FM>{{cite web |author1=Jamie Tabberer |title=Never forget: 9 gay icons who lost their lives to HIV and AIDS|url=http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/never-forget-9-gay-icons-who-lost-their-lives-hiv-and-aids011214/ |website=Gay Star News|accessdate=September 6, 2015 |date=December 1, 2014}}</ref> In 1992, John Marshall of ''[[Gay Times]]'' expressed the following opinion: "[Mercury] was a 'scene-queen,' not afraid to publicly express his gayness, but unwilling to analyse or justify his 'lifestyle' ... It was as if Freddie Mercury was saying to the world, 'I am what I am. So what?' And that in itself for some was a statement."<ref name="Leung">Helen Hok-Sze Leung. "Undercurrents: Queer Culture and Postcolonial Hong Kong". p. 88. HBC Press.</ref> Many assumed him to be either gay or bisexual<ref>{{cite news |publisher=BBC News |title=Zanzibar angry over Mercury bash |publication-date=September 1, 2006 |location=London|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5306792.stm |date=September 1, 2006 |accessdate=January 4, 2010}};{{cite news |last=Fitzpatrick|first=Liam|title=Farookh Bulsara|series=60 Years of Asian Heroes|periodical=Time Magazine, Asia Edition |volume=168 |issue=21 |publication-date=November 13, 2006 |publisher=Time Asia |location=Hong Kong |url=http://time.com/time/asia/2006/heroes/at_bulsara.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228152302/http://www.time.com/time/asia/2006/heroes/at_bulsara.html|archivedate=December 28, 2008}}</ref> and not [[sexually active]].<ref name=RS1>{{cite news |last1=Gilmore |first1=Mikhal |title=Queen's Tragic Rhapsody|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/queens-tragic-rhapsody-20140707 |accessdate=September 6, 2015 |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=July 7, 2014}}</ref> He would often distance himself from his later partner, Jim Hutton, during public events.<ref name="Hutton_1994">{{citation|last=Hutton|first=Jim|last2=Waspshott|first2=Tim|year=1994|title=Mercury and Me|place=London|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=0-7475-1922-6}}</ref> On the evening of November 24, 1991, Mercury died at the age of 45 at his home in Kensington of [[AIDS]]-related illnesses ([[bronchopneumonia|bronchial pneumonia]]).<ref name=otd>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/24/newsid_2546000/2546945.stm |title=1991: Giant of rock dies |publisher=News.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=September 27, 2014 |date=November 24, 1991}}</ref>

|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/25-essential-gay-pride-songs-rolling-stone-editor-picks-w486762/diana-ross-im-coming-out-w487328 |title=25 Essential Gay Pride Songs: Rolling Stone Editor Picks – Rolling Stone |publisher=Rollingstone.com |date=2017-06-12 |accessdate=2018-10-21}}</ref> which brought a significance to the phrase of "[[Coming out]]."
{{double image|left|Cher by Ian Smith.jpg|170|Madonna MDNA Vancouver.jpg|170|[[Cher]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] are renowned gay icons.||A Caucasian female with shoulder-length hair chemically dyed auburn with cool, brown colored makeup smiles, looking off to the right in front of a black background.|A blonde Caucasian female in a calico blouse and a silver chain smiles while looking to the left and slightly downward in front of a flesh-toned backdrop.}}
[[Cher]] became notable in the gay community not only for her music, but also her drag, her leather outfits of the 80s made her popular with the leather crowd.<ref name="Straight Parents">{{cite book |last=Bernstein |first=Robert |title=Straight Parents, Gay Children: Keeping Families Together |publisher=Thunder's Mouth Press |year=2003 |page=166 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=RJ5-svzhDuMC |isbn=1-56025-452-1}}</ref> In later years, her son [[Chaz Bono]] came out as gay at the age of 17 (and many years later as a transgender man), much to his mother's initial feelings of "guilt, fear and pain".<ref name="Straight Parents" /> When Cher was able to accept her son's sexual orientation, she realized that Chaz, as well as other LGBT people, "didn't have the same rights as everyone else, [and she] thought that was unfair".<ref name="Mother Power">{{cite book |last=Plumez |first=Jacqueline Hornor |title=Mother Power |publisher=Sourcebooks, Inc. |year=2002 |page=182 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=atozg9Eq2WsC |isbn=1-57071-823-7}}</ref> Cher emerged not only as an icon among LGBT people, but also as a role model for straight parents who have gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender children.<ref name="Straight Parents" /> She became the keynote speaker for the 1997 national Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays (PFLAG) convention.<ref name="Straight Parents" /><ref name="Mother Power" /> Cher's longevity in the music industry has often been credited to her gay following.<ref name="Gay Pride">{{cite book |last=Mann |first=William J. |title=Gay Pride: A Celebration of All Things Gay and Lesbian |publisher=Citadel Press |year=2004 |page=14 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=bw60KNSQNpoC |isbn=0-8065-2563-0}}</ref> [[William J. Mann]], author of ''Gay Pride: A Celebration of All Things Gay and Lesbian,'' comments "[w]e'll be dancing to a 90-year-old Cher when we're 60. Just watch".<ref name="Gay Pride" />
Continuing into the 1980s, pop music singer [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]—dubbed the "Queen of Pop" and "Queen of Dance" by the media, and later the "World's Most Successful Female Recording Artist" by ''[[Guinness World Records]]''—became the preeminent gay icon of the late 20th century.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cross |first=Mary |title=Madonna: A Biography |publisher=Canongate U.S. |year=2004 |isbn=0-313-33811-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Edith |last=Bowman |url=http://www.visionariesdebate.com/visionaries.php?id=3 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080525082816/http://www.visionariesdebate.com/visionaries.php?id=3 |archivedate=May 25, 2008|work=BBC News |title=BBC World Visionaries: Madonna Vs. Mozart|quote=In 2000, Guinness World Records listed Madonna as the most successful female recording artist of all time. |date=May 26, 2007|accessdate=May 12, 2008}}</ref><ref name="Madonna">{{cite web |last=Gdula |first=Steve |url=http://advocate.com/exclusive_detail_ektid22479.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061119044955/http://www.advocate.com/exclusive_detail_ektid22479.asp |archivedate=November 19, 2006 |title=Happy Madonna day! |date=November 11, 2005 |accessdate=July 9, 2008}}</ref> ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]''s Steve Gdula commented "[b]ack in the 1980s and even the early 1990s, the release of a new Madonna video or single was akin to a national holiday, at least among her gay fans."<ref name="Madonna" /> Gdula also stated that during this period, concurrent with the rise of the [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] epidemic, "when other artists tried to distance themselves from the very audience that helped their stars to rise, Madonna only turned the light back on her gay fans and made it burn all the brighter."<ref name="Madonna" />
[[Georges Claude Guilbert]], author of ''Madonna As Postmodern Myth: How One Star's Self-Construction Rewrites Sex, Gender, Hollywood and the American Dream'', writes that Madonna's reverence as a gay icon is equated with that of Judy Garland, noting similarities between the two popular culture icons.<ref name="guilbert">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=alWJbuRimhwC |title=Madonna As Postmodern Myth: How One Star's Self-Construction Rewrites Sex, Gender, Hollywood and the American Dream |publisher=McFarland |isbn=0-7864-1408-1 |first=Georges-Claude |last=Guilbert |year=2002 |accessdate=July 9, 2008}}</ref> Guilbert writes that gay icons "usually belong to one or the other of two types of female stars: either the very vulnerable or suicidal star, or the strong idol whom nobody or nothing resists, like Madonna."<ref name="guilbert" /> According to ''[[Madonna: An Intimate Biography]]'', the pop star has always been aware that her most loyal fans were gay men, has appeared in gay-oriented magazines as an [[Activism|activist]] for gay rights, and was even named in the book ''The Gay 100'' as one of the most influential gay people in history.<ref name="An-intimate-biography">{{cite book |last=Taraborrelli |first=J. Randy |title=Madonna: An Intimate Biography |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=2002 |page=147 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=yj1PTnse9-gC |isbn=0-7432-2880-4}}</ref>
[[File:Cyndi Lauper at Gay Games VII.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Cyndi Lauper]] performed in a [[Rainbow flag (gay movement)|rainbow]] dress at the closing ceremonies of the [[Gay Games]] VII (2006).]] Other superstar recording artists, including [[Cyndi Lauper]], followed.<ref name=lauper>{{cite web|url=http://www.equalityforum.com/mail/mail2005g.html |title=Cyndi Lauper to Perform at National Forum |work=Equality Forum press release |date=February 24, 2005 |accessdate=August 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070607164956/http://www.equalityforum.com/mail/mail2005g.html |archivedate=June 7, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Lauper and Madonna were seen as trailblazers of women's [[Sexual revolution|sexual liberation]].<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Creekmur | first1 =Corey K. |last2=Doty |first2=Alexander|title=Out in Culture: Gay, Lesbian, and Queer Essays on Popular Culture |publisher=Duke University Press |year=1995 |page=420 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=KOKX0_QfdpgC |isbn=0-8223-1541-6}}</ref> Lauper's debut album ''[[She's So Unusual]]'' (1983) generated a large following of fans responding to the "gay-friendly camp and lesbian-friendly womyn power epitomized in [her] femme anthem '[[Girls Just Want to Have Fun]]'."<ref name="she-still-bops">{{cite web |last=Stites |first=Jessica |title=She Still Bops |publisher=The Advocate |date=June 30, 2008 |url=http://www.advocate.com/exclusive_detail_ektid56889.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726211545/http://www.advocate.com/exclusive_detail_ektid56889.asp |archivedate=July 26, 2008 |accessdate=July 11, 2008}}</ref> Lauper explained that growing up during the 1960s influenced her dedication to fair and equal treatment of all people, noting that the music of the 1960s "helped to open the world's point of view to change."<ref name="rock-the-vote">{{cite web|last=Lauper |first=Cyndi |title=Here's Where I'm Coming From |publisher=The Advocate |date=June 11, 2008 |url=http://www.advocate.com/Arts_and_Entertainment/Music/Here_s_Where_I_m_Coming_From/ |accessdate=July 11, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628202200/http://www.advocate.com/Arts_and_Entertainment/Music/Here_s_Where_I_m_Coming_From/ |archivedate=June 28, 2011 |df= }}</ref> According to Lauper "It wasn't until my sister came out in the early [1970s] that I became more aware of the bigoted slurs and the violence against a community of people...who were gay."<ref name="rock-the-vote" /> Lauper has since become an active gay rights activist, often encouraging LGBT people and their allies to vote for equal rights.<ref name="rock-the-vote" /> Political activism for LGBT rights was the theme of Lauper's annual [[True Colors Tour]].
[[File:Oprah Winfrey (2004).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Oprah Winfrey]] is credited by many in the US as allowing gay people to become mainstream, due to her popularization of the tabloid talk show genre.]]
In the mid- to late-1980s, [[Oprah Winfrey]] emerged as an icon for the gay community with an intimate confessional communication style that altered the cultural landscape. According to the book ''Freaks Talk Back'' by Yale sociologist [[Joshua Gamson]], the [[tabloid talk show]] genre popularized by Oprah Winfrey and [[Phil Donahue]], did more to make gay people mainstream and socially acceptable than any other development of the 20th century by providing decades of high-impact media visibility for sexual nonconformists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/presssite/metadata.epl?mode=synopsis&bookkey=40916 |title=Freaks Talk Back: Tabloid Talk Shows and Sexual Nonconformity, Gamson |publisher=Press.uchicago.edu |accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0879727527 |title=Coming after Oprah: Cultural Fallout in the Age of the TV Talk Show (9780879727529): Vicki Abt, Leonard Mustazza: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref>
Fellow gay icon [[Ellen DeGeneres]] cast Winfrey to play the therapist she comes out of the closet to on the controversial episode of her ''[[Ellen (TV series)|Ellen]]'' sitcom. Though Winfrey abandoned her tabloid talk show format in the mid-1990s as the genre became flooded by more extreme clones like [[Ricki Lake]], [[Jenny Jones (presenter)|Jenny Jones]] and [[Jerry Springer]], she continued to broadcast shows that were perceived as gay-friendly. Her show ''[[Oprah's Big Give]]'' was the first reality TV show with an openly gay host [[Nate Berkus]]. Her own show has been nominated several times for [[GLAAD Media Award]]s, and another in 2010 for an interview with Ellen DeGeneres and her wife [[Portia de Rossi]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.queerty.com/glaad-glad-name-media-award-nominees-20080121/ |title=GLAAD Glad Name Media Award Nominees / Queerty |publisher=Queerty.com |date=January 21, 2008 |accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref> winning one in 2007<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.keithboykin.com/arch/2007/03/27/patti_labelle_w |author1=Kieth Boykin |title=Patti LaBelle Wins GLAAD Media Award |work=Kiethboykin.com |date=March 27, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121222209/http://www.keithboykin.com/arch/2007/03/27/patti_labelle_w |archivedate=November 21, 2008 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=October 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/media/story/2010/03/14/glaad-media-awards.html |title=Cynthia Nixon, Joy Behar win gay media awards – Arts & Entertainment – CBC News |publisher=CBC |location=Canada |date=March 14, 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317132740/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/media/story/2010/03/14/glaad-media-awards.html |archivedate=March 17, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Oprah Winfrey also co-produced the Oscar-winning film ''[[Precious: Based on the Novel "Push" by Sapphire|Precious]]'' (2009), which was honored by GLAAD for portraying a lesbian couple as heroines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moviefone.ca/2010/01/13/precious-a-single-man-among-glaad-nominees/ |title='Precious,' 'A Single Man' Among GLAAD Nominees |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706185853/http://www.moviefone.ca/2010/01/13/precious-a-single-man-among-glaad-nominees/ |archivedate=July 6, 2011 |accessdate=October 1, 2016}}</ref>
Winfrey's iconic status among gay males has entered the popular culture. One of the stars of the reality TV show ''[[The Benefactor (TV series)|The Benefactor]]'' was a gay African American man named Kevin who was so obsessed with Winfrey that he would ask "What would Oprah do?" before making any strategic decision. [[Adam Lambert]] is another high-profile gay man who has described himself as a fan of Winfrey.<ref>{{cite web |author=Catriona Wightman |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/ustv/news/a195328/lambert-really-excited-about-oprah.html |title=Lambert "really excited" about Oprah |publisher=Digitalspy.com |date=January 10, 2010 |accessdate=October 1, 2016}}</ref> Other icons from this decade include [[Joan Collins]], [[Tori Amos]], [[Tina Arena]], [[Harvey Fierstein]], and [[Stevie Nicks]].<ref name="POP" /><ref name="Afterelton" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.au.timeout.com/sydney/gay-lesbian/features/198/tina-arena-spectacular |title=Tina Arena Spectacular - Gay & Lesbian - Time Out Sydney |publisher=Au.timeout.com |date= |accessdate=May 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519165135/http://www.au.timeout.com/sydney/gay-lesbian/features/198/tina-arena-spectacular |archivedate=May 19, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pridesource.com/article.shtml?article=27542 |title=Queen of Quirky |accessdate=March 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071106002521/http://www.pridesource.com/article.shtml?article=27542 |archivedate=November 6, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaywired.com/article.cfm?id=19681&section=67 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206171020/http://www.gaywired.com/article.cfm?id=19681&section=67 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 6, 2008 |title=Thank You for Being a Friend; Golden Girls' Estelle Getty Dead at 84 |accessdate=July 24, 2008 |last=Taylor |first=Maggie |date=July 22, 2008 |work=GayWired.com}}</ref><ref name=JoanCollins>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/joan-collins-shes-younger-by-the-minute-682194.html |title=Joan Collins: She's younger by the minute |first=Marcelle |last=D'Argy |date=April 22, 2001 |accessdate=April 14, 2010 |work=The Independent |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.qtmagazine.com/article.cfm?section=22&id=16495 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014040900/http://qtmagazine.com/article.cfm?section=22&id=16495 |archivedate=October 14, 2007 |title=Diva Annie Lennox Sings... Live... |work=GTMagazine |date=September 2007 |accessdate=September 29, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://rockalittle.com/article_innews_weekly_may2_2001.htm |title=In News Weekly May 2, 2001 Nicks of Time By Lawrence Ferber |publisher=Rockalittle.com |date=May 2, 2001 |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Staff |first=Magazine |title=Gay Entertainment Report: Stevie Nicks As Gay Icon |url=http://www.ontopmag.com/article.aspx?id=4185&MediaType=1&Category=27 |publisher=On Top Magazine |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909141536/http://www.ontopmag.com/article.aspx?id=4185&MediaType=1&Category=27 |archivedate=September 9, 2012 |accessdate=October 1, 2016 |df=mdy }}</ref>
=====1990s===== [[File:JanetJacksonUnbreakableTourSanFran2015.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Janet Jackson performing on her [[Unbreakable World Tour (Janet Jackson tour)|Unbreakable World Tour]] in 2015]] [[Janet Jackson]], who twice was established as one of the highest-paid recording artists in the history of contemporary music during the 1990s, [[Janet Jackson as gay icon|became a gay icon]] after she released her sixth studio album ''[[The Velvet Rope]]'' (1997).<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Goldberg | first1 = M. |title=The Jacksons score big |page=32 |work=Rolling Stone |date=May 2, 1991 |url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=9104291442&loginpage=login.asp&site=ehost-live&scope=site | issn = 0035-791X|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Janet Jackson Hits Big; $80 Million Record Deal | newspaper=[[Newsday]] |pages=A02 |date=January 13, 1996}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last1=McCormick |first1=Neil |title=The Arts: Give her enough rope... Reviews Rock CDs |work=The Daily Telegraph |page=11 |date=October 18, 1997}}</ref> The album was honored by the National Black Lesbian and Gay Leadership Forum and received the award for Outstanding Music Album at the 9th Annual [[GLAAD Media Awards]] in 1998 for its songs that dealt with sexual orientation and [[homophobia]].<ref name="GLAAD">{{cite web|url=http://www.glaad.org/media/release_detail.php?id=4308 |title=Janet Jackson to be Honored at 19th Annual GLAAD Media Awards in Los Angeles |accessdate=April 1, 2008 |last=McCarthy |first=Marc |work=[[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation|GLAAD]] |date=April 1, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409095931/http://www.glaad.org/media/release_detail.php?id=4308 |archivedate=April 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> On April 26, 2008, she received the [[GLAAD Vanguard Award|Vanguard Award]]—a media award from the [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]]—to honor her work in the entertainment industry in promoting equality for LGBT people.<ref name="GLAAD" /> GLAAD President [[Neil Giuliano|Neil G. Giuliano]] commented, "Ms. Jackson has a tremendous following inside the LGBT community and out, and having her stand with us against the defamation that LGBT people still face in our country is extremely significant."<ref name="GLAAD" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gaywired.com/article.cfm?section=10&id=6391 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051023190056/http://www.gaywired.com/article.cfm?section=10&id=6391 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-10-23 |title=La Toya Jackson Learns Life's Lessons|work=gaywired.com |date=June 2005 |accessdate=December 21, 2007}}</ref>
[[Deborah Cox]] quickly becomes a gay icon due to her investment for the fight against the AIDS but also and especially thanks to club remixes included in her singles, which are frequently played in the discothèques.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rule |first=Doug |url=http://www.metroweekly.com/feature/?ak=5060 |title=The Musical Empowerment of Deborah Cox – Metro Weekly |publisher=Metroweekly.com |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gayly.com/gaylys-exclusive-interview-sensational-deborah-cox |title=Gayly's exclusive interview with the sensational Deborah Cox |publisher=The Gayly |date= |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watermarkonline.com/2011/05/26/deborah-cox-returns-to-orlando-for-gaydays/ |title=Deborah Cox returns to Orlando for GayDays |publisher=Watermark Online |date= |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref>
Writer, composer and singer, [[Ysa Ferrer]] is regarded as the French "[[Kylie Minogue|Kylie]]". Her dance/electro style, called "Pop Kosmic" is very popular in France and Russia especially in the gay community where she is considered as a true icon.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.lavoixdunord.fr/Locales/Metropole_Lilloise/actualite/Secteur_Metropole_Lilloise/2011/06/04/article_ysa-ferrer-icone-gay-star-en-russie-veut.shtml |title=Ysa Ferrer, icône gay, star en Russie, veut élargir son public, ce soir à Lille - La Voix du Nord |publisher=Lavoixdunord.fr |date= |accessdate=May 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427031152/http://www.lavoixdunord.fr/Locales/Metropole_Lilloise/actualite/Secteur_Metropole_Lilloise/2011/06/04/article_ysa-ferrer-icone-gay-star-en-russie-veut.shtml |archivedate=April 27, 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nordeclair.fr/Sorties/Spectacles/2010/02/13/ysa-ferrer-bouillonnante-icone-gay.shtml |title=Nordeclair.fr |publisher=Nordeclair.fr |date= |accessdate=May 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426201856/http://www.nordeclair.fr/Sorties/Spectacles/2010/02/13/ysa-ferrer-bouillonnante-icone-gay.shtml |archivedate=April 26, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
[[Glenn Close]] was established as a gay icon after portraying [[Margarethe Cammermeyer]] in ''[[Serving in Silence: The Margarethe Cammermeyer Story|Serving in Silence]]'' (1995). She gained more recognition through her campy portrayal of the glamorous [[Cruella de Vil]] in [[101 Dalmatians (1996 film)|''101 Dalmatians'']] (1996) and as the fading diva [[Norma Desmond]] in the Broadway musical [[Sunset Boulevard (musical)|''Sunset Boulevard'']].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/celebrity/glenn-close-yep-im-a-gay-icon/|title=Glenn Close: Yep, I'm a Gay Icon!|date=2002-04-30|newspaper=PEOPLE.com|language=English|access-date=2016-12-24}}</ref>
[[Garth Brooks]], whose sister is openly lesbian, was one of the first non-LGBT male artists to openly back gay rights, and later same-sex marriage.<ref name="Garth Brooks">{{cite web|title=Garth backs us gays=dallasvoice|date=July 12, 1996|url=http://m.dallasvoice.com/garth-brooks-back-good-gay-folks-10200687.html?mobile-redirector-transfer=true|accessdate=July 12, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170102082640/http://m.dallasvoice.com/garth-brooks-back-good-gay-folks-10200687.html?mobile-redirector-transfer=true|archivedate=January 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
[[The Spice Girls]] became gay icons during the 1990s,<ref name="Emma Bunton Interview">{{cite web|url=http://dancemusic.about.com/od/artistshomepages/a/EmmaBuntonInt_3.htm |title="Emma Bunton Interview" |publisher=dancemusic.about.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.li/20050917141334/http://dancemusic.about.com/od/artistshomepages/a/EmmaBuntonInt_3.htm |archivedate=September 17, 2005 |df=mdy-all }} Retrieved 13 February 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/9847145/G-A-Y-founder-takes-back-nightclub-chain-from-HMV.html |title=G-A-Y founder takes back nightclub chain from HMV |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref> on account of their dance-pop sound, flamboyant outfits, outgoing personalities and affirmations of equality. [[Geri Halliwell]], in particular, went on to become a gay icon in her own right during her solo career in the 2000s, covering [[The Weather Girls]]' classic gay anthem, "[[It's Raining Men]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/feature/?ak=3037 |title=Geri Power – Metro Weekly |publisher=Metroweekly.com |date=November 10, 1999 |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Top 50 gay icons">[http://www.femin.co.uk/?PageID=116&NewsID=636 Top 50 gay icons]. femin.co.uk. Retrieved 17 January 2008. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080125023010/http://www.femin.co.uk/?PageID=116&NewsID=636 |date=January 25, 2008 }}</ref> In 2016, Halliwell received the Honorary Gay Award at the annual [[Attitude (magazine)|Attitude Awards]].<ref name="attitude awards 2016">{{cite web|url=http://attitude.co.uk/interview-geri-horner-talks-spice-girls-solo-regrets-and-her-kinship-with-the-gay-community/ |title=Interview: Geri Horner talks Spice Girls, solo regrets, and her kinship with the gay community|publisher=[[Attitude (magazine)|Attitude]] |date=5 January 2017 |accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref>
====21st century====
=====2000s===== [[File:Kylie_Brazil_2015_(2).jpg|160px|thumb|upright|[[Kylie Minogue]] has an international gay following.]] The main single of [[I Turn to You (Melanie C song)|I Turn to You]] by [[Melanie C]], which became a gay anthem, was released as the "Hex Hector Radio Mix", for which [[Hex Hector]] won the 2001 [[Grammy]] as [[Grammy Award for Remixer of the Year, Non-Classical|Remixer of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jan/04/entertainment/ca-8072/13|title=Grammys Cast a Wider Net Than Usual|page=13|work=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Tribune Company|first=Geoff|last=Boucher|accessdate=April 29, 2011|date=January 4, 2001}}</ref>
Following her "[[Ride It (Geri Halliwell song)|Ride It]]" single in 2004, which became a gay anthem, [[Geri Halliwell]] confirms her gay icon status.<ref name="Top 50 gay icons"/><ref name="PinkHitParade">{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/the-pink-hit-parade-sing-if-youre-glad-to-be-gay-422423.html | title = The pink hit parade: Sing if you're glad to be gay | work = The Independent | accessdate = 26 April 2009 | location=London | date=1 November 2006}}</ref>
[[Kylie Minogue]] reinvented herself musically in the first decade of the 21st century and found herself faced with a renewed and increasing gay fanbase.<ref name="Sutherland and Ellis, p. 47">Lucy Ellis, Bryony Sutherland. Kylie "Talking": Kylie Minogue in Her Own Words. Omnibus Press, 2003. {{ISBN|978-0-7119-9834-6}}. p. 47</ref><ref name="ThinWhiteDame">{{cite web | last = Ives | first = Brian |author2=Bottomley, C. | title = Kylie Minogue: Disco's Thin White Dame |work=VH1 | date = February 24, 2004 | url = http://www.vh1.com/artists/interview/1485255/02232004/minogue_kylie.jhtml | accessdate =January 21, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Kylie's greatest gay icon ever">{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article6978.ece |title=Kylie's greatest gay icon ever |publisher=The Sun |date=September 8, 2007 |accessdate=April 9, 2012 |location=London}}</ref> She said, "My gay audience has been with me from the beginning ... they kind of adopted me."<ref name="ThinWhiteDame"/> Minogue first became aware of her gay audience in 1988, when several [[drag queen]]s performed to her music at a Sydney pub, and she later saw a similar show in Melbourne. [[Wayne Koestenbaum]]; [[HarperCollins|Forth Estate]]; 1996</ref> and [[Jóhanna Sigurðardóttir]], the [[List of the first LGBT holders of political offices|first openly lesbian]] [[head of government]] of the [[modern era]].<ref name="time">{{Cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1875032,00.html |title=Iceland Picks the World's First Openly Gay PM |first=Jonas |last=Moody|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=January 30, 2009 |accessdate=January 31, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7863923.stm|title = First gay PM for Iceland cabinet |publisher=BBC News |date=February 1, 2009 |accessdate=February 1, 2009}}</ref> [[Roger Casement]], an Irish civil rights activist, became a gay icon of the early 20th century.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1= Lewis | first1 = Brian | title= The Queer Life and Afterlife of Roger Casement | journal=Journal of the History of Sexuality |volume = 14 | issue = 4 | pages = 363–82 | publisher=HW Wilson |year = 2005 | url = http://vnweb.hwwilsonweb.com/hww/results/getResults.jhtml?_DARGS=/hww/results/results_common.jhtml.21 | doi = 10.1353/sex.2006.0040}}</ref> Civil rights activist [[Coretta Scott King]] was held in high regard among members of the gay community for her involvement in the [[Gay Rights Movement]].<ref name="Coretta" /> During her lifetime, she routinely equated the goals of the [[Civil Rights Movement]], led by her late husband [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], with that of LGBT activism.<ref name="Coretta" />
{{Quote|I still hear people say that I should not be talking about the rights of lesbian and gay people and I should stick to the issue of racial justice... But I hasten to remind them that Martin Luther King Jr. said "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere."... I appeal to everyone who believes in Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream to make room at the table of brother- and sisterhood for lesbian and gay people.<ref name="Coretta" />|Coretta Scott King|''[[Metro Weekly]]''}}
San Francisco City Supervisor [[Harvey Milk]] was [[List of lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender firsts by year|the first openly gay man to be elected to office in the U.S.]] and spearheaded the defeat of statewide [[Briggs Initiative|anti-gay ballot measure Proposition 6]] in California in 1978. While he and Moscone were assassinated shortly thereafter, both became viewed as martyrs for gay rights. Milk's image as a positive role model led to him becoming the namesake for the first high school designed primarily for gay teenagers, the [[Harvey Milk High School]], in the East Village of New York City.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27939377/ |title=Milk |author=AP (no byline) |date=November 27, 2008 |work=Article |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=January 22, 2010}}</ref> The portrayal of those efforts in the [[Milk (film)#Critical reception|critically acclaimed]] film ''[[Milk (film)|Milk]]'' earned [[Sean Penn]] an [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Oscar]] and comparisons to the contemporary battle over the anti-gay ballot initiative [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]] raging in California at the time of the film's release in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/movies/reviews/2008/milk.html |title=Milk |author=Brett McCracken |date=November 26, 2008 |work=Film Review |publisher=Christianity Today |accessdate=January 22, 2010}}</ref>
An ironic icon is [[Anita Bryant]], who worked to oppose homosexuality.<ref name="Anita Bryant">{{cite web|last=Steele |first=Bruce C. |title=Milestones |publisher=The Advocate |date=November 12, 2002 |url=http://www.advocate.com/issue_story_ektid22690.asp |accessdate=July 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202123232/http://www.advocate.com/issue_story_ektid22690.asp |archivedate=December 2, 2008}}</ref> During the 1970s, Bryant led a national campaign, "[[Save Our Children]]", that conflated homosexuality and [[pedophilia]] and insisted that, because homosexuals cannot reproduce, they must "recruit" or "convert" people to their lifestyle.<ref name="SOC">{{cite book |last=Sagert |first=Kelly Boyer |title=The 1970s |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2007 |page=34 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=FPHZbVhQQTUC |isbn=0-313-33919-8}}</ref> California State Senator [[John Briggs (politician)|John V. Briggs]] applauded Bryant's work as a "national, religious crusade [and] courageous stand to protect American children from blatant homosexuality".<ref name="SOC" /> However, as Bruce C. Steele of ''The Advocate'' wrote, Bryant's crusade against the Gay Rights Movement made her synonymous with it.
{{Quote|About 10 years ago, I was at an American Booksellers Association convention where Bryant was ... still pissing and moaning about how the homosexuals had destroyed her career as spokesperson for Florida orange juice. The irony is, it wasn't the orange juice boycott that caused her to lose her job; it was the fact that she made herself forever associated with homosexuality. So, in one way, she was a victim of homophobia herself: Folks on the orange board didn't want people to think about queers when they bought orange juice."<ref name="Anita Bryant" />|as told to Bruce C. Steele| ''The Advocate''}}
According to John Coppola, exhibit curator and former head of exhibits at the [[Smithsonian Institution]] in Washington, DC, "In a completely unintended way, Anita Bryant was about the best thing to happen to the gay rights movement ... She and her cohorts were so over the top that it just completely galvanized the gay rights movement".<ref name="Mother">{{cite web |title=Celebrating Anita Bryant: The Mother of Gay Rights |publisher=Pensito Review |date=July 4, 2007 |url=http://www.pensitoreview.com/2007/06/04/celebrating-anita-bryant-the-mother-of-gay-rights |accessdate=July 14, 2008}}</ref> The 30th anniversary of Bryant's campaign against LGBT rights has been commemorated at the [[Stonewall Library & Archives]], with executive director Jack Rutland dubbing her "The Mother of Gay Rights".<ref name="Mother" />
==Fictional== Various fictional characters have been regarded as gay icons, including cartoon figures. [[Bugs Bunny]], a fictional [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] rabbit appearing in animation by [[Warner Bros. Cartoons]] during the [[Golden Age of American animation]]—dubbed the greatest cartoon character of all time by ''[[TV Guide]]''—has been declared a "queer cultural icon [and] parodic diva" due to his "cross-dressing antics" and camp appeal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bugs Bunny tops greatest cartoon characters list |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/TV/07/30/cartoon.characters/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=July 30, 2002 |accessdate=February 27, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208043937/http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/TV/07/30/cartoon.characters/index.html |archivedate=February 8, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Murray |first=Raymond |title=Images in the Dark: An Encyclopedia of Gay and Lesbian Film and Video |publisher=TLA Publications |year=1994 |page=455 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iGxZAAAAMAAJ |isbn=1-880707-01-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=McGowan |first=Kate |title=The Year's Work in Critical and Cultural Theory: 1995 |publisher=Blackwell Publishing |year=1998 |page=129 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=T7pSf0PZteEC |isbn=0-631-20896-8}}</ref>
Some comic book characters are considered gay icons. Homosexual interpretations of [[Batman]] and the original [[Robin (comics)|Robin]], [[Dick Grayson]], have been of interest in cultural and academic study, due primarily to psychologist [[Fredric Wertham]]'s ''[[Seduction of the Innocent]]'' (1954).<ref name="The Complete History">{{cite book |last=Daniels |first=Les |author2=Chip Kidd |title=Batman: The Complete History |publisher=Chronicle Books |year=2004 |page=69 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=73wknu2cVIkC |isbn=0-8118-4232-0}}</ref> In the mid-1950s, Wertham led a national campaign against comic books, convincing Americans that they were responsible for corrupting children and encouraging them to engage in acts of sex and violence.<ref name="The Complete History" /> In relation to Batman and Robin, Wertham asserted "the Batman type of story helps to fixate homoerotic tendencies by suggesting the form of an adolescent-with-adult or [[Ganymede (mythology)|Ganymede]]-[[Zeus]] type of love-relationship".<ref name="Seduction">{{cite book |last=Bosmajian |first=Haig A. |title=Burning Books |publisher=McFarland |year=2006 |page=202 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=UkAXPuObVBUC |isbn=0-7864-2208-4}}</ref>
In ''Containing America: Cultural Production and Consumption in Fifties America'', authors Nathan Abrams and Julie Hughes point out that homosexual interpretations of Batman and Robin existed prior to Wertham's ''Seduction of the Innocent''.<ref name="Fifties America">{{cite book |last=Abrams |first=Nathan |author2=Julie Hughes|title=Containing America: Cultural Production and Consumption in Fifties America |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |year=2005 |page=163 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qhLZsBLjV28C |isbn=1-902459-06-7}}</ref> Wertham claimed his book was, in fact, prompted by the earlier research of a California psychiatrist.<ref name="Fifties America" /> The relationship between Batman and arch villain the [[Joker (comics)|Joker]] has also been interpreted by many as homoerotic. [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]], author of ''[[The Dark Knight Returns]]'', has described the relationship between Batman and the Joker as a "homophobic nightmare," and views the character as sublimating his sexual urges into crime fighting, concluding, "He'd be much healthier if he were gay."<ref name=batman>{{cite book |last=Sharrett |first=Christopher |chapter=Batman and the Twilight of the Idols: An Interview with Frank Miller |title=The Many Lives of the Batman: Critical Approaches to a Superhero and His Media |publisher=Routledge |location=London |year=1991 |isbn=0-85170-276-7 |pages=37–38}}</ref>
One TV series that appeals most to [[LGBT culture]] is the 1960s sitcom ''[[Bewitched]]''. Aside from the campy characterizations, it contained three gay cast members ([[Dick Sargent]], [[Paul Lynde]] and—allegedly—[[Agnes Moorehead]]). Star [[Elizabeth Montgomery]] and Sargent were grand marshals of a Los Angeles [[gay pride parade]] in the early 1990s. Another example is [[Bianca Montgomery]] of ''[[All My Children]]''.<ref name="WWW.afterellen.com">{{cite web|first=Lisa |last=Yimm |title=Olga Sosnovska, AMC's Unlikely Lesbian Icon |publisher=[[AfterEllen.com]] |date=April 2004 |accessdate=April 7, 2008 |url=http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/TV/amc-olga.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080116110907/http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/TV/amc-olga.html |archivedate=January 16, 2008 |df=mdy }}</ref>
==Responses== [[File:Tammy Faye Messner.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Tammy Faye Messner]] went from [[Televangelism|televangelist]] to gay icon.]] Many celebrities have responded positively to being regarded as gay icons, several noting the loyalty of their gay fans. [[Eartha Kitt]] and Cher credited gay fans with keeping them going at times when their careers had faltered.<ref name=gbl>{{cite book |last=Rutledge |first=Leigh W. |title=The Gay Book of Lists, 3rd Edition |publisher=[[Alyson Publications]] |year=2003 |location=Los Angeles, CA |pages=87–88 |isbn=1-55583-740-9}}</ref> Kylie Minogue has acknowledged the perception of herself as a gay icon and has performed at such events as the [[Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras]]. Asked to explain the reason for her large gay fanbase, Minogue replied, "It's always difficult for me to give the definitive answer because I don't have it. My gay audience has been with me from the beginning ... they kind of adopted me." She noted that she differed from many gay icons who were seen as tragic figures, with the comment, "I've had a lot of tragic hairdos and outfits. I think that makes up for it!"<ref name=kyliecomment>{{cite web |last=Ives |first=Brian |author2=Bottomley, C. |title=Kylie Minogue: Disco's Thin White Dame |publisher=[[VH1]].com |date=February 24, 2004 |accessdate=January 21, 2007 |url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/interview/1485255/02232004/minogue_kylie.jhtml}}</ref>
[[Tammy Faye Messner]] (ex-wife of fellow controversial [[televangelist]] [[Jim Bakker]] and mother of pastor [[Jay Bakker]]), who benevolently has been referred to as "the ultimate drag queen,"<ref name="tfbakker">{{cite news |last=Wilson-Smith |first=Anthony |title=Tammy Faye's Fab Fan Club |work=[[Maclean's]] |page=7 |date=May 22, 2000}}</ref>  said in her last interview with [[Larry King]] that, "When I went—when we lost everything, it was the gay people that came to my rescue, and I will always love them for that."<ref name="tfbakker2">{{cite news |last=Rabey |first=Steve |title=Tammy Faye, gay icon |work=[[Christianity Today]] |pages=85–86 |date=October 2, 2000}}</ref>
Others have been more ambivalent. [[Mae West]], a gay icon from the early days of her career, supported [[gay rights]] but bristled when her performance style was referred to as camp.<ref name=maewest>{{cite book |last=Watts |first=Jill |title=Mae West: An Icon in Black and White |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]], USA |year=2001 |location=New York |page=300 |isbn=0-19-510547-8}}</ref>
Madonna has acknowledged and embraced her gay following throughout her career, even making several references to the gay community in her songs or performances, and performed at several gay clubs. She has declared in interviews that some of her best friends are gay and that she adores gay people and refers to herself as "the biggest gay icon of all times."<ref name=madonnainterview>{{cite web |url=http://uk.gay.com/headlines/9191 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051028054912/http://uk.gay.com/headlines/9191 |archivedate=October 28, 2005 |title=Madonna: 'I hope I'm still a gay icon' |work=[[Gay.com]] |date=October 26, 2005 |accessdate=August 1, 2007}}</ref> She also has been quoted in television interviews in the early 1990s as declaring the "big problem in America at the time was homophobia."
