'''Two-way communication''' is a form of [[transmission (telecommunications)|transmission]] in which both parties involved transmit [[information]]. Two-way communication has also been referred to as interpersonal communication. Common forms of two-way communication are:
* [[Amateur|Amateur Radio]], [[CB radio|CB]] or [[Family Radio Service|FRS]] radio contacts. * [[Chatroom]]s and [[Instant Messaging]]. * [[Computer network]]s. See [[backchannel]]. * In-person [[communication]]. * [[Telephone]] conversations.
A cycle of communication and two-way communication are actually two different things. If we examine closely the anatomy of communication – the actual structure and parts – we will discover that a cycle of communication is not a two-way communication in its entirety. Meaning, two way communication is not as simple as one may infer. One can improve two-way or interpersonal communication by focusing on the eyes of the person speaking, making eye contact, watching body language, responding appropriately with comments, questions, and paraphrasing, and summarizing to confirm main points and an accurate understanding.<ref>{{cite web|title=Improving Interpersonal Communication|url=http://www.utmb.edu/ombudsman/pdf/Improving_Interpersonal_Communication_Techniques.pdf|publisher=University of Texas Medical Branch}}</ref>
Two-way communication is different from one-way communication in that two-way communication occurs when the receiver provides feedback to the sender. One-way communication is when a message flows from sender to receiver only, thus providing no feedback. Some examples of one-way communication include: radio or television programs or even listening to policy statements from top executives. Two-way communication is especially significant in that it enables feedback to improve a situation.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Two-Way Communication in Business?|url=http://bizcommunicationcoach.com/what-is-two-way-communication-in-business/|website=Business Communication|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref>
Two-way communication involves feedback from the receiver to the sender. This allows the sender to know the message was received accurately by the receiver. Communication is also negotiated which means that the sender and receiver listen to each other, the messages then gathers information to respond. One person is the sender, which means they send a message to another person via face to face, email, telephone, etc. The other person is the receiver, which means they are the one getting the senders message. Once receiving the message, the receiver sends a response back. For example, Person A sends an email to Person B --> Person B responds with their own email back to Person A. The cycle then continues. This chart demonstrates two-way communication and feedback.
[Sender] <--------- | \ [Encoding] \ | | [Channel] [Feedback] | | [Decoding] / | / [Receiver]---------->
Two-way communication may occur horizontally or vertically in the organization. When information is exchanged between superior and subordinate, it is known as vertical two-way communication. On the other hand, when communication takes place between persons holding the same rank or position, it is called horizontal two-way communication. Two-way communication is represented in the following diagrams: (Cite: https://thebusinesscommunication.com/two-way-communication-and-importance/)
(Superior)---------------> (Subordinate)---------------> (Superior) (Information) (Feedback)
There are many different types of two-way communication systems, and choosing which is best to use depends on things like the intended use, the location, the number of users, the frequency band, and the cost of the system. “Regardless of the type of system chosen, the one common feature is that all of the components must be compatible and work together to support a common purpose.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://study.com/academy/lesson/what-is-two-way-communication-definition-systems-examples.html#transcriptHeader|title=What Is Two-Way Communication? - Definition, Systems, & Examples|last=Fenner|first=Susan|date=|website=Study.com|archive-url=|archive-date=2017-12-20|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Amateur Radio, Citizen Band Radio, and Family Radio Service == [[Amateur Radio]] is used for entertainment and as a hobby by many groups of people. These individuals label themselves as “Hams.” Amateur Radios are also known to be a reliable means of communication when all other forms are not operating. In times of disaster, communication through Amateur radios has led to lives being saved.<ref name=Amateur>{{cite web|title=What Is Amateur Radio?|url=http://www.arrl.org/what-is-amateur-radio|publisher=The National Association for Amateur Radio|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref> [[Citizens band radio]], CB radio, can be used by anyone who is not a member of a foreign government. It is meant for short range communication using devices that mimic walkie-talkies.<ref name=CB>{{cite web|title=Citizens Band (CB)|url=http://www.fcc.gov/encyclopedia/citizens-band-cb-service|publisher=FCC Encyclopedia|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref> [[Family Radio Service]], FRS, is also meant for short range communication using devices that mimic walkie-talkies. Like the CB radio, the FRS does not require a license and can be used by anyone who is not a member of a foreign government.<ref name=FRS>{{cite web|title=Family Radio Service (FRS)|url=http://www.fcc.gov/encyclopedia/family-radio-service-frs|publisher=FCC Encyclopedia|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref>
== Chat Rooms and Instant Messaging == [[Instant messaging]] became wildly popular around 1996 and spread even more with AOL in 1997. The concept behind IM is that it is a way of quick communication between two people due to tools such as knowing when messages are seen or knowing when others are online. Many social media sites have integrated IM into their sites as ways to spread communication. [[Chat rooms|Chat Rooms]] are very similar, only they are messages to a group of people. Chat rooms are often public; meaning that you can send a message and anyone can freely join the “room” and view the message as well as respond.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tyson|first=Jeff|title=How Stuff Works- Instant Messaging|url=http://im.about.com/gi/o.htm?zi=1/XJ&zTi=1&sdn=im&cdn=compute&tm=22&f=10&tt=2&bt=5&bts=75&zu=http%3A//communication.howstuffworks.com/instant-messaging.htm|publisher=Discovery|accessdate=2014-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Roos|first=Dave|title=How Stuff Works- Chat Rooms|url=http://computer.howstuffworks.com/internet/social-networking/information/chat-room.htm|publisher=Discovery|accessdate=2014-03-19}}</ref>
== In-person communication == As it relates to business, 75% of people believe in-person communication is critical. In-person interaction is useful for resolving problems more efficiently, generating long-term relationships, and resolving a problem or creating an opportunity quickly. 4 out of 6 of the most important attributes of building a relationship cannot be achieved without the power of in-person, which requires a rich communication environment. Business executives believe in-person collaboration is critical for more than 50 percent of key business strategic and tactical business processes when engaging with colleagues, customers, or partners.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Power of In-Person Communication|url=http://www.cisco.com/web/telepresence/economist-infographic.html|publisher=Cisco|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref>
== Telephone conversations == The [[telephone]] is a device that is relatively easy to understand and use. In fact, the telephone connections used today have remained remarkably unchanged compared to those used almost a century ago. In addition, your connection to the phone company is rather straightforward as well. The telephone makes it easy to connect instantly with others from all over the world, making it simple to have a two-way conversation with a neighbor or with someone many miles away. Phones have undergone some changes over the years. Today, for example, phones use electronic switches instead of operators. The switch uses a dial tone so that when you pick up the phone you are aware that both the switch and the phone are functioning properly.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brain|first=Marshall|title=How Stuff Works- How Telephones Work|url=http://electronics.howstuffworks.com/telephone.htm|publisher=HowStuffWorks,LLC.|accessdate=2014-03-19}}</ref>
== Computer networks == Computer networks are used to have two-way communication by having computers exchange data. Ways that this is possible is wired interconnects and wireless interconnects. Types of wired interconnects are Ethernets and fiber optic cables. Ethernets connect local devices through Ethernet cables. Fiber runs underground for long distances and is the main source of Internet in most homes and businesses. Types of wireless interconnects include Wi-Fi and Bluetooth. The problem with these networks is that they don't have unlimited connection span. To expand the reach there are wide area interconnects such as satellite and cellular networks. Also, there are long distance interconnects which need ''backhaul'' to move the data back and forth and ''last mile'' to connect the provider to the network.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mitchell|first=Bradley|title=How Computer Networks Work- Introduction to Interconnects|url=http://compnetworking.about.com/od/basicnetworkingconcepts/a/how-computer-networks-work-introduction-to-interconnects.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=2014-03-19}}</ref>

A '''unisex name''' (also known as an '''epicene name''', a '''gender-neutral name''' or an '''androgynous name''') is a [[given name]] that can be used by a person regardless of their sex. Unisex names are common in the English speaking world, especially in the United States. By contrast, some countries have [[Naming laws|laws]] preventing unisex names, requiring parents to give their children sex-specific names.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-21280101</ref> In other countries, unisex names are sometimes avoided for social reasons such as potential [[discrimination]], ridicule, and [[psychological abuse]].<ref>https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/09/19/banned-baby-names_n_12090708.html</ref>
Names may have different gender connotations from country to country or language to language. For example, the Italian [[male name]] ''[[Andrea]]'' (derived from Greek ''Andreas'') is understood as a [[female name]] in many languages, such as English, German, Hungarian, Czech, and Spanish.
Parents may name their child in honor of a person of another sex, which – if done widely – can result in the name becoming unisex. For example, Christians, particularly [[Catholics]], may give a child a second/middle name of the opposite sex, e.g. name a son Marie or Maria in honor of the [[Virgin Mary]] or formerly [[Anne]] for [[Saint Anne]]; or name a daughter José in honor of [[Saint Joseph]] or Jean in honor of [[John the Baptist]]. This practice is rare in English-speaking countries.
Some masculine and feminine names are [[homophone]]s, pronounced the same for both sexes but spelled differently. For example, [[Yves (given name)|Yves]] and [[Eve (name)|Eve]] and (for some speakers) [[Artemus (disambiguation)|Artemus]] and [[Artemis (disambiguation)|Artemis]]. These names are not strictly unisex names.
==In popular culture== Unisex names can be used as a source of humor, such as [[Julia Sweeney]]'s sexually ambiguous character "[[Pat (Saturday Night Live)|Pat]]" on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. A running joke on the TV show ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'' is that almost every woman J.D. sleeps with has a unisex name: Jordan, Alex, Danni, Elliot, Jamie, Kim, etc. Similarly, the sex of the baby Jamie in ''[[Malcolm in the Middle]]'' was purposely kept ambiguous when first introduced at the end of the show's fourth season to build suspense. In ''[[Gilmore Girls]]'', Rory is bothered by the discovery that her boyfriend Logan's workmate Bobby, is female. Rory had assumed Bobby was male and it is only upon their first meeting that Rory discovers Bobby's gender.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rory and Logan: Getting Serious|url=http://crushable.com/entertainment/rory-logan-getting-serious/|publisher=Crushable|accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref> The name "Rory" was historically a male name until ''Gilmore Girls'' reached popularity, at which point the name reached rough gender parity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nancy.cc/2011/02/09/rory-boy-name-or-girl-name/|title=Rory – Boy Name or Girl Name?|date=2011-02-09|website=Nancy's Baby Names|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref>
In Japanese [[dramas]] and [[manga]], a unisex name may be given to an [[androgynous]] or [[gender-bending]] character as part of a plot twist to aid in presenting the character as one sex when they are actually another.
In mystery fiction, unisex names have been used to tease readers into trying to solve the mystery of a character's sex. The novels of [[Sarah Caudwell]] feature a narrator named Hilary Tamar, a law professor who is never identified as either male or female.
==African== {{See also|African-American names}} Unisex names of African origin include:

====Zimbabwe==== {{See also|Zimbabwean names}} Shona, a Bantu group in Zimbabwe, have unisex names<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.momjunction.com/articles/shona-baby-names-for-girls-boys_00407419/#gref|title=50 Zimbabwean Shona Baby Names For Girls And Boys|date=23 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref> which may indicate the circumstances of the baby or the family during the time of the birth. All Shona names have a meaning, some also celebrate virtue or worship God. Popular unisex names in the Shona ethnic group<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.20000-names.com/androgynous_names_unisex_names_04.htm|title=20000-NAMES.COM|first=|last=20000-names.com|publisher=}}</ref>are:
* Akatendeka (God is faithful) * Anenyasha (God is merciful) * Anesu (God is with us) * Chipo (Gift) * Farai (Rejoice) * Kudzai (Worship) * Nyasha (Mercy) * Rufaro (Happiness) * Shingirayi (Persevere) * Tendai (Grateful) * Tafadzwa (Joyful) * Tanaka (We are good) * Tatenda (We give thanks) * Vimbai (Trust)

===Indian languages=== {{See also|Indian family names}} Many [[languages of India|Indian]] names become unisex when written with Latin characters because of the limitations of [[transliteration]]. The spellings ''Chandra'' and ''Krishna'', for example, are transliterations of both the masculine and feminine versions of those names. In Indian languages{{Fix|text=in which alphabets?}}, the final ''a'' in each of these names are different letters with different pronunciations, so there is no ambiguity. However, when they are seen (and usually, spoken) by someone unfamiliar with Indian languages, they become sexually ambiguous. Other Indian names, such as ''Ananda'', are exclusively or nearly exclusively masculine in India, but because of their ''a'' ending, are assumed to be feminine in Anglophone societies.
Many unisex names in India are obvious and ridiculed. For instance [[Nehal]], Sonal, Snehal, Niral, Pranjal and Anmol are used commonly to name baby boys or girls in western states of [[India]] such as [[Gujarat]]. Similarly, names like Kajal, Sujal, Viral, Harshal, Deepal, Bobby, Mrinal, Jyoti, Shakti, [[Neelam (given name)|Nilam]], [[Kiran (given name)|Kiran]], [[Lucky (name)|Lucky]], Ashwini, Shashi, Malhar, Umang, Shubham and Anupam are also very common sex-neutral names or unisex names in India. Most [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] [[Sikh]] first names such as "Sandeep, Gurdeep, Kuldeep, Mandeep", "Surjeet, Gurjeet, Kuljeet, Harjeet, Manjeet", "Harpreet, Gurpreet, Jaspreet, Kulpreet, Manpreet", "Prabhjot, Harjot, Gurjot, Jasjot" and "Sukhjinder, Bhupinder, Jasbinder, Parminder, Kulvinder, Harjinder, Ranjodh, Sheeraz, Hardeep, Kirandeep, Sukhdeep, Govindpal, Encarl, Rajan" are unisex names and equally commonly given to either sex.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhnames.com/|title=Sikh Names (SikhNames.com) Sikh Names, Meanings & Pronunciation|first=sikhnames.com -|last=http://www.sikhnames.com|publisher=}}</ref> Also, names derived from Dari Persian and Arabic, but not used among native speakers of those languages, are common among South Asian Muslims. Since Persian does not assign genders to inanimate nouns, some of these names are gender-neutral, for example Roshan, Parveen, and Insaaf.

===Finnish=== {{See also|Finnish name}} Finnish law bans giving "female child a male name and male child a female name"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/ajantasa/1985/19850694 |title=FINLEX ® - Ajantasainen lainsäädäntö: 9.8.1985/694 |publisher=Finlex.fi |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29|language=fi}}</ref> among other restrictions. Some ambiguous names do exist, which have been given to children of both sexes. A partial list includes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinginuutiset.fi/artikkeli/162854-lapsesta-ruu-tai-sirius-sukupuolineutraaleista-nimista-tuli-buumi |title=Lapsesta Ruu tai Sirius? Sukupuolineutraaleista nimistä tuli buumi | Helsingin Uutiset |publisher=Helsinginuutiset.fi |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29|language=fi}}</ref><!-- It says on the article they have checked these names from väestörekisteri for having been given for both sexes.
Further, I reduced the list a bit according my arse feel of what of these could pass as first names. Even if the law does not make any difference between first name and the rest, I think it is safe to say the official processing the name form will be really stringent only on the first name. That can't be tested, because the publicly accessible name database does not differentiate on order. -->
{{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * Aala * Airut * Aleksa * Alvi * Ara * Ariel * Asla * Dana * Eedi * Eelia * Eeri * Eka * Ensi * Ervi * Hani * Heile * Helgi * Helle * Ilo * Jessi * Kaari * Kaiho * Karli * Karo * Kullero * Lahja * Lemmi * Lumo * Marin
{{col-2}} * Marjus * Mietti * Miska * Mitja * Muisto * Niika * Niki * Nilla * Noe * Oma * Orla * Peeta * Rani * Reine * Reita * Sana * Sani * Sassa * Sirius * Soini * Soma * Sävel * Tiera * Toive * Vanja * Venni * [[Vieno]] * Viivi * Vilka {{col-end}} Many of these names are rare, foreign or neologism, established names tend to be strongly sex-specific. Notably, a class of names that are derived from nature can be often used for either sex, for example: '''Aalto''' (wave), '''Halla''' (frost), '''Lumi''' (snow), '''Paju''' (willow), '''Ruska''' (fall colors), and '''Valo''' (light). Similarly, there are some (sometimes archaic) adjectives which carry no strong gender connotations, like '''Kaino''' (timid), '''Vieno''' (calm) or '''Lahja''' (a gift). Certain names can have unisex diminutives, such as Alex, which can be short for Aleksandra or Aleksanteri (or variants thereof).
===French=== {{See also|French name}} Popular unisex names of French origin include:
{{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * [[Alix (given name)|Alix]] * Amour * [[Avril (name)|Avril]] * [[Beau (name)|Beau]] * [[Camille (given name)|Camille]] * Candide * [[Celeste (name)|Céleste]] * Claire * Claude * [[Cyrille]] * Delain, Delaine * [[Dominique (name)|Dominique]] * [[Hyacinthe]] * Jade * Jeryn
{{col-2}} * [[Jocelyn]] * [[Lacy]] * Laurence * [[Lillian (name)|Lillian]] * [[Louison]] * [[Marron (disambiguation)|Marron]] * Maxime * Monet * [[Narcisse]] * Placide * [[Quentin]] * [[René]] * Stéphane * [[Yannick]] {{col-end}} There are also pairs of masculine and feminine names that have slightly different spelling but identical pronunciation, such as André / Andrée, Frédéric / Frédérique and Gabriel / Gabrielle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://french.about.com/od/culture/a/frenchnames_4.htm|title=Patterns of French First Names - Prénoms Français|publisher=}}</ref> In [[France]] and French-speaking countries, it can happen for people to have a combination of both masculine and feminine given names, but most of these include "Marie", such as Jean-Marie, Marie-Jean, Marie-Pierre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://french.about.com/od/culture/a/frenchnames.htm|title=Patterns of French First Names - Prénoms Français|publisher=}}</ref> [[Marie (given name)|Marie]] was a unisex name in medieval times; it is nowadays only female except for its presence in compound names. Notable examples of people with a combination of masculine and feminine given names are [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]] (male), [[Marie-Jean Hérault de Séchelles]] (male), [[Marie-Pierre Kœnig]] (male), and [[Marie-Pierre Leray]] (female).
European royals often bear the name Marie, the French form of [[Maria (given name)|Maria]], in their names. [[Prince Amedeo of Belgium, Archduke of Austria-Este]] (Amedeo '''Marie''' Joseph Carl Pierre Philippe Paola Marcus), [[Prince Jean of Luxembourg]] (Jean Félix '''Marie''' Guillaume), and [[Jean, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] (Jean Benoît Guillaume Robert Antoine Louis '''Marie''' Adolphe Marc) are examples of male royals who bear Marie in their names.
===German=== {{See also|German name}} In the past, [[Germany|German]] law required parents to give their child a sex-specific name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/LIVING/07/03/mf.baby.naming.laws/index.html|title=Oh no, you can't name your baby THAT! - CNN.com|author=David K. Israel|publisher=Mental Floss}}</ref><ref>Flippo, Hyde "The Germany Way" Published by McGraw-Hill (1996), Pages 96-97</ref> This is no longer the case, since the [[Constitutional Court|Federal Constitutional Court of Germany]] held in 2008 that there is no obligation for a name to be sex-specific, even if the child has only one given name.<ref>[http://www.bverfg.de/entscheidungen/rk20081205_1bvr057607.html BVerfG, 1 BvR 576/07 vom 5.12.2008], paragraph 16</ref> The custom of adding a second name which matches the child's legal sex is no longer required. Still, unisex names of German origin are rare, most of them being nicknames rather than formal names (such as Alex).
Examples of unisex names include:
* Eike * Evelyn * [[Gabi (disambiguation)|Gabi]] * Gustl (the male variant is a shortening of ''August'' or ''Gustav'', the female for ''Augusta'') * [[Heike (given name)|Heike]] * [[Inge]] * Kai * Kim * [[Micha]] * Michi * [[Niko (disambiguation)|Niko]] * [[Sigi (disambiguation)|Sigi]] * Toni * Ulli * Willy * Zell

===Icelandic=== {{See also|Icelandic name}} Unisex names are in general illegal in Iceland (the given name ''Blær'' one of the few exceptions, the first reversal by a judge (and accepted will not be appealed to the [[Supreme Court of Iceland|Supreme Court]]) of former denial (as a female name);<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/5918||title=Mál nr. 17/2013 Eiginnafn: Blær (kvk.) |trans-title=Case 17/2013 Given name: Blær (female) |website=Department of Justice: Úrskurðir og álit |language=is|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref> and e.g. ''Auður'' later approved for males,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/6748|title=Mál nr. 73/2013 Eiginnafn: Auður |website=Department of Justice: Úrskurðir og álit |language=is|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref> while ''Alex'' was denied for females later that the same year<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/6761|title=Mál nr. 76/2013 Eiginnafn: Alex |quote=Beiðni um eiginnafnið '''Alex''' (kvk.) er hafnað. [Request for given name '''Alex''' (female) is denied.] |website=Department of Justice: Úrskurðir og álit |language=is|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref>). The [[Icelandic Naming Committee]] (Icelandic: ''Mannanafnanefnd'') has preapproved lists of male and female names (with e.g. ''Ofur''<!--https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/5916--> (e. Super or Uber), ''Lady'',<!--https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/6045--> and ''X''<!--https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/4710--> (as middle name) declined, and for instance ''Þyrnirós''<!--https://www.urskurdir.is/domsogkirkjumala/mannanafnanefnd/nr/6157--> (e. [[Sleeping Beauty]], while literally meaning ''a rose with [[thorns, spines, and prickles|thorn]]s'') is approved for females).
Additionally traditional patronymic (or rarely matronymic or both) [[Icelandic name|Icelandic last names]] (by law) cannot be unisex. The suffix of the last name ''-dóttir'' ("daughter") is used for female sex; males use the suffix ''-son'' (rare exceptions for foreign females: when using husband's last name as a family name; family names are in general illegal with few exceptions). Given names are also clearly (to Icelanders) masculine or feminine, and [[linguistic gender]] has to match the gender identity of the person.<ref>{{cite journal| url=http://www.csw.ucla.edu/publications/newsletters/academic-year-2008-09/article-pdfs/Jun09_willson.pdf |title=Name Law and Gender in Iceland| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923211628/http://www.csw.ucla.edu/publications/newsletters/academic-year-2008-09/article-pdfs/Jun09_willson.pdf |archivedate=23 September 2015 |publisher=UCLA Center for the Study of Women |date=9 June 2009}}</ref>
{{As of|2012}}, the law has been successfully challenged once, for the given male name ''Blær'' (transliterated Blaer) which was exceptionally allowed to be used for females. The Icelandic Naming Committee had for 14 years rejected the registration of Blær as a girl's name in the national census, and the girl in question was registered with the default given name ''stelpa'' ("girl") as the name was not on the list of about 1,853 approved female names. A lower court deemed the name additionally legal for females<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-21280101 |title=Icelandic girl Blaer wins right to use given name |publisher=BBC |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=7 September 2014}}</ref> and the state decided not to use its right to appeal.
Among the few exceptions to the gender agreement rule are the traditional name [[Sturla Þórðarson|Sturla]], linguistically feminine, from medieval history always applies to males; and Ilmur ("fragrance" or "odour"), linguistically masculine, must apply to females.
===Irish=== {{See also|Irish name}}
* [[Ailbhe (disambiguation)|Ailbhe]] * Aran * [[Brogan]] * Carey * [[Carling (given name)|Carling]] * Casey * Finley * [[Flann]] * [[Flannery]] * Kerry * Nollaig * Ryan * Shannon * [[Shea (disambiguation)|Shea]] * [[Sláine]] * [[Teagan (disambiguation)|Teagan]] * [[Tierney]]
===Italian=== {{See also|Italian name}} In Italy, unisex names are very rare. There are basically male names like i.e. [[Andrea]] (which is female i.e. in English, Spanish, German or French), Elia or Mattia that can also be given to females. Names like Celeste, Amabile, [[Fiore (disambiguation)|Fiore]], [[Loreto (disambiguation)|Loreto]], or Diamante are, as opposite, female names that occasionally can be given to males.
Sometimes "Maria" is used as a middle male name (such as Antonio Maria).
"Rosario" (feminine: "Rosaria") is a male name in Italian whereas in Spanish is female.
There are also unisex nicknames, i.e. Giusi or Giusy that can stand either for Giuseppe or Giuseppina, respectively "Joseph" and "Josephine"; Dani or Dany which stand for Daniele (male) or Daniela (female); Alex that can stand for Alessandro (male) as well as for Alessandra (female); Fede (literally: "Faith") that can stand either for Federico or Federica.
===Portuguese=== {{See also|Portuguese name}}
* Carmo * Cruz
====Brazilian==== Names that end with an ''i'' are considered unisex in Brazil. They tend to be Native Brazilian [[Tupi people|Indian]] names in origin, such as Araci, Jaci, Darci, Ubirani, but names from other cultures are now being absorbed, such as Remy, Wendy, and Eddy. Names that end with ''ir'' and ''mar'' tend to be unisex also, such as Nadir, Aldenir, Dagmar and Niomar - though in these cases there are some exceptions.
===Russian=== {{See also|Eastern Slavic naming customs}}
Diminutive forms of names in Russian language can be unisex, such as Sasha/Shura (Alexandr or Alexandra), Zhenya (Yevgeniy or Yevgeniya), Valya (Valentin or Valentina), Valera (Valeriy or Valeriya), [[Slava (disambiguation)|Slava]] (for names ending with -slav or -slava).
===Slovene=== * Fran (diminutive of Frančiška) * Ivica (diminutive of ''Ivan'' (John) or ''Ivana'' (Joanne)) * Saša (diminutive of ''Aleksander'' (Alexander)) * Slava (diminutive of Slavko) * Vanja (diminutive of Ivan or Ivana)
===Spanish=== {{See also|Spanish naming customs}} In Spain, unisex names are extremely rare. María, an originally feminine name is used in Spanish for males as second name, very commonly after José (e.g., [[José María]]). José is used for females preceded by María ([[María José]]). Also [[Guadalupe (name)|Guadalupe]], a feminine name is sometimes used as masculine after José (José Guadalupe). More names given to both genders include [[Carmen (name)|Carmen]], Inés, [[Reno (given name)|Reno]], [[Trinidad (disambiguation)|Trinidad]], [[Nazaret]], [[Reyes (disambiguation)|Reyes]], and [[Celes (disambiguation)|Celes]].
Like in English, some common nicknames are unisex such as Álex ([[Alejandro]], [[Alejandra]]), Cris ([[Cristina (disambiguation)|Cristina]], [[Cristiano (given name)|Cristian]], [[Cristóbal (disambiguation)|Cristóbal]]), Dani ([[Daniel]], [[Daniela]]).
==Cross-cultural== Some names are masculine in one culture and feminine in another, so that when these cultures mix in a third location, the same name appears unisex. Some example are:
* [[Adel (name)|Adel]], a masculine name in Arabic and Persian-speaking countries, and a female name in Jewish-speaking countries or Hungarian as Adél * Aki, a male name in Finland and Nigeria, and unisex in Japan * [[Ami (given name)|Ami]], a feminine name in Japan and English-speaking countries but unisex in Hebrew-speaking countries and India * [[Eli (name)|Eli]], a masculine name of Hebrew origin in English and Jewish-speaking countries and a feminine name in Spanish, Norwegian, and Danish-speaking countries * Jules, masculine in French but unisex in English-speaking countries * [[Karen (name)|Karen]], a female name in America, parts of Europe and Asia, and masculine in Armenia, Kurdistan, and Iran * [[Kiko (given name)|Kiko]], masculine in Spanish, Portuguese, and South America and feminine in Japan * [[Manu (disambiguation)|Manu]], masculine in Finland and parts of India, and unisex in parts of Europe such as France and Germany * [[Mao (given name)|Mao]], a feminine name in Japan and a masculine name in [[Limburg (Belgium)|Limburg]] * [[Miho]], female in Japan and male in Croatia * Mika, a male name in Finland and a female name in Japan * Moe, masculine in English-speaking countries and feminine in Japan * Naomi, a feminine name in America, Europe and Hebrew-speaking countries, and unisex in Japan * Nima, masculine in Persia but unisex in Arabic * Olie, a unisex name in English-speaking countries, and a feminine name in Indonesia * Ren, feminine in Taiwan and unisex in Japanese and English-speaking countries * [[Yury|Yuri]], a male name in Russia and [[Yuri (Japanese name)|Yuri]] or [[Yu-ri (Korean name)|Yu-ri]], a female name in Japan and Korea

{{Infobox publisher | image = | parent = | status = | founded = 2013 | founders = C.P. Heiser, Olivia Taylor Smith | successor = | country = [[United States]] | headquarters = [[Los Angeles, California]] | distribution = [[Publishers Group West]] (USA) | keypeople = | publications = | topics = | genre = Literary fiction and nonfiction | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|http://www.unnamedpress.com}} }}
'''Unnamed Press''' is an independent publisher based in [[Los Angeles, California]]. Unnamed Press publishes [[literary fiction]] and [[non-fiction]], with an emphasis on debuts by women, underrepresented voices and people of color, as well as internationally focused speculative and fantasy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Unnamed Press > About|url=http://www.unnamedpress.com/about|website=Unnamed Press}}</ref> Its art director, Jaya Nicely, is an LA-based illustrator and designer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jaya Nicely > About|url=http://www.jayanicely.com/about/}}</ref>
==History==
Unnamed Press was founded in 2013 by C.P. Heiser and Olivia Taylor Smith after meeting in 2011 at the [[Los Angeles Review of Books]] and was originally intended to be an ebook-only publisher, focused on genre fiction set outside of the United States.<ref name=PW2015> {{cite web|last1=Gross|first1=Anisse|title=Unnamed Press Creating Home For Contemporary Authors|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/65736-unnamed-press-creating-home-for-contemporary-authors.html|publisher=Publishers Weekly}}</ref> The press began with early success in publishing global fiction from Deji Bryce Olukotun (''Nigerians in Space''), [[Kristiina Ehin]] (''Walker on Water''), and [[Kazi Anis Ahmed]] (''Good Night, Mr. Kissinger'').<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nawotka|first1=Edward|title=LA’s Unnamed Press: Relatable Foreign Fiction, Unlikely Protagonists|url=https://publishingperspectives.com/2014/07/las-unnamed-press-relatable-foreign-fiction-unlikely-protagonists/|publisher=Publishing Perspectives|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> It quickly evolved to a traditional publishing model, and now releases between 12 and 15 print titles per year.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ulin|first1=David L.|title=Talking with the publishers of new L.A.-based Unnamed Press|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-talking-with-la-publisher-unnamed-press-20140422-story.html|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> In 2018, Unnamed Press reached a milestone of 50 books published.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ulin|first1=David L.|title=How Small, Scrappy Local Book Presses Have Turned L.A. Into a Publishing Town|url=http://www.lamag.com/culturefiles/small-book-presses/|publisher=Los Angeles Magazine|ref=Los Angeles (magazine)}}</ref> Unnamed Press is distributed by [[Publishers Group West]].<ref name=PW2015 />
==Publishing== Authors published by Unnamed Press include Jessie Chaffee, Malu Halasa, [[Agnès Desarthe]], Saad Z. Hossain, [[Stefan G. Bucher]], Margaret Wappler, Janet Capron, David Ulin, [[Henrietta Rose-Innes]], Kazi Anis Ahmed, Merle Kröger, [[James Boice (writer)]], [[Janice Pariat]], J.M. Servin, among others.<ref>{{cite web|title=Unnamed Press > Books|url=http://www.unnamedpress.com/books}}</ref>
In 2016, Unnamed author Esmé Weijun Wang was selected as a [[Granta]] [https://granta.com/issues/best-young-american-novelists-3/ Best Young American Novelist] for her debut novel ''Border of Paradise'', released by the press that same year. Esmé was also selected as a 2018 [[Whiting Award]] winner for her forthcoming collection of essays from [[Graywolf Press]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2018 Whiting Award Winners|url=https://www.whiting.org/writers/awards/current-winners|publisher=Whiting Foundation|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref>
In 2017, Unnamed published ''After the Flare'' by Deji Bryce Olukotun — a follow-up science fiction thriller and sequel to the first book issued by the press (''Nigerians in Space''). ''After the Flare'' was named a finalist and won Special Citation for the 2018 [[Philip K. Dick Award]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2018 Philip K. Dick Award Winner Announced|url=http://www.philipkdickaward.org/2018/04/2018-philip-k-dick-award-winner-announced.html|publisher=Philip K. Dick Award|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref>

The '''Voluntary System of Accountability''' ('''VSA''') and its '''College Portraits''' website is a college search tool for prospective students and an accountability tool for public institutions.<ref name=Fullerton>{{cite web|title=About the Voluntary System of Accountability (VSA) College Portrait Project|url=http://www.fullerton.edu/collegeportrait/|publisher=Fullerton|accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref>
Students and their families can use the College Portraits to find a presentation of comparable information that comes directly from public universities.<ref name=Michigan>{{cite web|title=College Portrait of Undergraduate Education|url=http://www.msu.edu/vsa/|publisher=Michigan State University|accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref>
Participating institutions use the College Portraits to highlight common information prospective students and families seek. College Portraits data elements include: admissions requirements, [[University student retention|retention]] and graduation rates, campus community highlights, academic programs, [[safety]], and [[cost of attendance]], to name a few. In 2010, a College Affordability Estimator [[net price calculator]] was added to help prospective students estimate their individual net cost to attend a specific university. The Estimator meets the requirements of the [[Higher Education Opportunity Act]].
Institutions and systems can use the College Portraits to meet accountability requirements from governing boards, [[state legislature (United States)|state legislatures]], state coordinating offices, and other outside groups, often reducing their burden and duplication of effort. The [[College Portraits]] can also be used during the accreditation process as evidence of student learning outcomes, institutional improvement, [[transparency (behavior)|transparency]], and commitment to the public good.<ref name=NSSE>{{cite web|title=NSSE and the Voluntary System of Accountability|url=http://nsse.iub.edu/html/vsa.cfm|publisher=NSSE|accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref>
The VSA is a joint project of the [[Association of Public and Land-grant Universities]] (APLU) and the [[American Association of State Colleges and Universities]] (AASCU) in collaboration with the higher education community.<ref name=Fullerton /> VSA institutions represent more than half of all public four-year institutions, 66 percent of all APLU members, and 60 percent of APLU and AASCU's joint membership. VSA participating institutions enroll 63 percent of [[undergraduate students]] attending public universities.

{{Italic title}} '''''Vortigern and Rowena''''', or '''''Vortigern, an Historical Play''''' is a [[Play (theatre)|play]] that was touted as a newly discovered work by [[William Shakespeare]] when it first appeared in 1796. It was eventually revealed to be a [[Shakespeare Apocrypha|Shakespeare hoax]], the product of prominent forger [[William Henry Ireland]].<ref name="NAE">{{Cite book | last = Ashe | first = Geoffrey | author-link = Geoffrey Ashe | contribution = (Samuel) William Henry Ireland | editor-last = Lacy | editor-first = Norris J. | title = The New Arthurian Encyclopedia | volume = | pages = 244 | publisher = Garland | place = New York | year = 1991 | contribution-url = | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> Its first performance was April 2, 1796, when it was ridiculed by the audience. Its titular protagonists, [[Vortigern]] and [[Rowena]], are figures from Britain's [[Matter of Britain|traditional history]].
==History== Ireland had produced several [[Ireland Shakespeare forgeries|earlier documents]] he claimed represented the writings of Shakespeare, but ''Vortigern and Rowena'' was the first play he attempted. He shortly followed it with a forged ''[[Henry II (play)|Henry II]]''. He had announced his "discovery" of the lost play as early as December 26, 1794, but did not show his father a manuscript until March 1795. He also provided a purported correspondence between Shakespeare and a printer explaining why the play was unpublished, as well as a deed accounting for how it came to be in hands of the Irelands.<ref>Kahan, pp. 62-66.</ref> According to the deed, Shakespeare had willed all the manuscripts to an ancestor of the Irelands, also named William Henry Ireland, who had saved him from drowning. Years later, Ireland explained that he came up with this story to establish his right to the manuscripts in case a descendant of the bard might claim them.<ref>William Henry Ireland, ''Authentic Account''. pp. 22-23.</ref>
Hearing of a newly recovered "lost" Shakespeare play, Irish playwright [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan]] purchased the rights to the first production at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane Theatre]] in [[London]] for 300 pounds and the promise of half the revenues to Ireland's family. After reading the play, Sheridan noted its relative simplicity compared to Shakespeare's known works. Actor [[John Philip Kemble]], the manager of Drury Lane, and who would play the title role in the play's only production, had serious doubts about ''Vortigern'''s authenticity. [[Sarah Siddons]], who had been cast as the title female role, dropped out one week before the scheduled opening for unknown reasons, though it is suspected that Kemble had successfully turned the famous actress against the work as well. <ref>Doug Stewart, ''The Boy Who Would be Shakespeare'' (2010) </ref> Irish Shakespearean scholar [[Edmond Malone]] published ''An Inquiry into the Authenticity of Certain Miscellaneous Papers and Legal Instruments'' on March 21, 1796, about the authenticity of ''Vortigern'' and the other documents "discovered" by Ireland. Siddons' role of ''Edmunda'' was taken by [[Mrs Powell]] when it opened on 2 April 1796.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/22641|title=Powell [Renaud], Jane (c. 1761–1831), actress|last=Crouch|first=K. A.|date=2004-09-23|publisher=Oxford University Press|series=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|language=en|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/22641}}</ref> The play did have its supporters; [[Henry James Pye]] and [[James Bland Burgess]] wrote prologues for it, while [[Robert Merry]] wrote an epilogue.<ref name="CamelotProject">{{cite web |url= http://www.lib.rochester.edu/camelot/ireland.htm|title= Vortigern |accessdate=December 3, 2008 |work= The Camelot Project|publisher= University of Rochester|date= }}</ref>
When ''Vortigern and Rowena'' opened on April 2, 1796, Kemble used the chance to hint at his opinion by repeating Vortigern's line "and when this solemn mockery is o'er," and the play was derided by the audience. It was never performed again until 2008. Some early critics accused William Henry Ireland's father Samuel of the forgery, though William assumed responsibility in two printed confessions. Samuel himself continued to regard the play as authentic and edited it in 1799, including a foreword in which he attacked Malone's findings and denounced the "illiberal and injurious treatment" he had received.<ref name="CamelotProject"/> Nevertheless, neither Ireland's reputation recovered from the fiasco, and William eventually moved to [[France]], where he lived for several decades. He tried to publish ''Vortigern and Rowena'' as his own work when he returned to England in 1832, but met with little success.<ref>Kahan, p. 207</ref>
==Characters== {{div col}} * [[Constans II (usurper)|Constantius]] – King of [[Great Britain|Britain]] * [[Ambrosius Aurelianus|Aurelius]] - A Brother of Constantius * [[Uther Pendragon|Uter]] - A Brother of Constantius * [[Vortigern]] - Adviser to Constantius * [[Vortimer|Wortimerus]] - A Son of Vortigern * [[Catigern|Catagrinus]] - A Son of Vortigern * [[Pascent|Pascentius]] - A Son of Vortigern * [[Hengest and Horsa|Hengist]] - Leader of the Saxon Mercenaries * [[Hengest and Horsa|Horsus]] - Brother of Hengist * Fool * Servant * Page * Barons, Officers, Guards, &c., &c. * Edmunda - Wife of Vortigern * Flavia - Daughter of Vortigern, Ambrosius' Lover * [[Rowena]] - Daughter of Hengist * Attendants on Edmunda {{div col end}}
==Synopsis== The story begins as the [[King of the Britons]] [[Constans II (usurper)|Constantius]] offers half his crown to his adviser Vortigern for his loyal service. Vortigern immediately plots the king's murder in order to take the crown for himself. Meanwhile, the court [[Jester|Fool]] warns two of Vortigern's children, [[Pascent]]ius and Flavia, of the bad times ahead and the three of them leave the court with Flavia in drag. Constantius' sons Aurelius ([[Ambrosius Aurelianus]]) and Uter ([[Uther Pendragon]]), studying in Rome, receive word of Vortigern's treachery and go to [[Scotland]] to raise an army against their father's killer. In response Vortigern summons an army of [[Saxons]], led by [[Hengist and Horsa|Hengist and Horsus]], to defend him from the Scots. He falls in love with Hengist's beautiful daughter [[Rowena]], and proclaims her his queen, much to the chagrin of his wife Edmunda and his two remaining sons, Wortimerus ([[Vortimer]]) and Catagrinus ([[Catigern]]), who flee. Vortigern's family eventually all join Aurelius and Uter's army, and Aurelius and Flavia declare their mutual love. In the end the Saxons are routed and Aurelius defeats Vortigern but spares his life, and then marries Flavia. The final speech is delivered by the Fool, who admits that the play is not very tragic, as "none save bad do fall, which draws no tear".<ref name="CamelotProject"/>
==Sources== Like other apocryphal plays attributed to Shakespeare, ''[[The Birth of Merlin]]'' and ''[[Locrine]]'', ''Vortigern and Rowena'' takes the [[Matter of Britain]] as its subject, drawing especially from [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]'s ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'' and [[Raphael Holinshed]]'s ''Chronicle'', the same source used by Shakespeare.<ref name="NAE"/> Shakespeare used Britain's mythical history in several of his plays, including ''[[King Lear]]'' and ''[[Cymbeline]]'', based on the stories of [[Leir of Britain]] and [[Cunobelinus]], respectively. The play is essentially a pastiche of Shakespeare, with Vortigern serving as a Macbeth figure; other Shakespearean elements include the use of Holinshead and Flavia's cross-dressing.<ref name="NAE"/>
==Modern revival== The play experienced a comedic revival by the [[Pembroke Players]] at the [[Pembroke College, Cambridge|Pembroke College]] New Cellars, [[Cambridge]], on November 19, 2008. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.camdram.net/shows/08/vortigern?type=view |title=Vortigern |publisher=Association of Cambridge Theatre Societies |work=CamDram.net - Shows |quote=Join the Pembroke Players for a one-night stand in the New Cellars on November the 19th [2008], possibly this play’s first performance for over two hundred years... |accessdate=January 19, 2014}}</ref> The production was directed by Pembroke third-year Alexander Whiscombe, and starred David Harrap in the title role with Eystein Thanisch as Aurelius.<ref>Winterbotham, Alex (November 20, 2008). [http://www.varsity.co.uk/reviews/1111/1/ "Vortigern"]. ''Varsity''. Retrieved December 3, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.camdram.net/shows/diary?term=24 "Shows"]. From camdram.net. Retrieved December 3, 2008.</ref> The [[American Shakespeare Center]] in [[Staunton, Virginia]] included the play as part of its [[Staged_reading|Staged Reading Series]] in November, 2013.<ref>[http://www.americanshakespearecenter.com/v.php?pg=1041 "What's Playing: Staged Reading Series"] From ascstaunton.com. Retrieved October 28, 2013.</ref>
